Imagine zooming in on a shape that stretches out forever—like an endless road. Physicists like to study such “non-compact” spaces, but their favorite math tool, the “spectral action,” was built only for neat, finite shapes. We give it new travel papers.  

We keep the algebra (the rule book for multiplying functions) open-ended, yet insist the Dirac operator—think of it as a universal speedometer—still packs its data into a small suitcase (its resolvent stays compact).  

A simple toy model, the supersymmetric harmonic oscillator (a fancy pendulum that can vibrate two ways), fits the bill. It supplies two different speedometers; each slices the space differently, and only their combined reading tells left from right.  

Computing the action for a tiny two-point universe shows the Higgs field feeling an extra spring force. Below a critical size everything is heavy; above it, only the Higgs keeps its weight while the others go massless. The switch is smooth, like water turning from liquid to vapor at one temperature.  

This shows how geometry size can trigger phase changes, giving us a fresh window into why particles might gain or lose mass.

output: Imagine that the “fine-structure constant,” a basic dial that controls how atoms hold together, has stayed the same since the Big Bang. Earlier studies using quirky quasar light claimed the dial has turned a tiny amount, but their error bars were unrealistically small. We built a cleaner ruler, applied it to one of the sharpest star-light spectra ever taken, and now say: if the dial has moved at all, the shift is smaller than 1 part in 10 million. We also checked a related dial—the proton-to-electron mass ratio—by looking at molecular hydrogen shadows in another quasar, and we tightened that limit too. Why care? If these dials ever shifted, our laws of physics would change across the universe. By tightening the bounds we sharpen our test of whether today’s physics is truly universal, and we show that future ultra-precise instruments could reach the sensitivity needed for a decisive check.

Think of a big bag of dots.  
We let a clock tick: each tick drops a new “patch” (a small group of randomly chosen dots).  
A dot is “identifiable” if it can be reached from any patch; a patch is “identifiable” only when every dot in it is reachable.  
We watch what happens when the clock speeds up: the fraction of identifiable dots and patches suddenly jumps at a sharp threshold—sometimes smoothly, sometimes with a snap—depending on how the patch sizes are chosen.  
The math shows that adding even a single extra patch can flip the system’s behaviour, a phase-transition result relevant to network reliability and search-and-rescue routing.

We built a smart “wind-Compensating” system that watches the wiggles, learns the pattern, and steers a flexible mirror so the beam stays sharp.

Imagine every city on a map has a “busy-ness” score.  
In 1997, two mathematicians asked: “Which road network of cities (a tree) keeps the total travel-time low when each city’s busy-ness score is taken into account?”  
We proved the best layout is the same one computers use to shrink file sizes: a Huffman tree.  
You start with the least busy cities and keep gluing them, bottom-up, to the next least-busy neighbor.  
No extra roads or loops are ever added.  

This tells planners, biologists, or data scientists how to connect points when each point has a different importance: always link the lightest, least important items first, and the whole system stays as compact as possible.

Imagine a line of tiny quantum “spins” that can be flipped into a special pattern: one is up, the rest are down.  
We turn these spins into a line of “fermions” (think of them as quantum coins that can’t land on top of each other).  
Even if the first pattern is a bit blurry—neighboring coins slightly tilted or every coin a bit noisy—the coins still keep a steady, shared “quantum link” (called discord).  
The link stays, but its shape changes: some pairs that were equally linked become unequal, so the tidy clusters of equally-linked coins can break apart.  

Why care?  
This steady link gives us a simple, robust way to store and move quantum information, even when the starting setup isn’t perfect.

Why care? Better measurements mean we can see how drugs or mutations change the zipper’s timing, helping doctors understand cell growth and cancer one day.

We studied a giant space “toothbrush”—a 4-million-light-year-long arc of radio waves in a swarm of galaxies called 1RXS J0603.  
When clusters crash, they should act like cosmic traffic jams: gas piles up, heats abruptly, and the temperature jump tells us the crash speed.  
Our thermometer, the Japanese Suzaku satellite, found the gas barely warms at the brush’s edge, so the speed is only half of what radio waves predict.  
That mismatch means the standard rule linking radio color to crash speed doesn’t work here.  
We double-checked with another X-ray telescope and got the same cool surprise.  
We also hunted for ultra-high-energy “inverse-Compton” light and saw none, proving the magnetic field inside the brush is at least a million times stronger than Earth’s.  
This tells us magnetic fields can store surprising amounts of energy inside the Universe’s largest collisions, reshaping how we read radio relics as speedometers.

Imagine two people holding dozens of walkie-talkies each, all talking at once.  
The air is messy: some signals are planned (the “deterministic” part), others bounce around randomly (the “random multipath” part).  
We bundle these countless paths into one big mathematical “box” called a random operator and count how many signals fit inside—similar to asking how many songs can squeeze into a shuffling playlist.

We then measure how much information every receive antenna actually hears.  
When both sides keep adding antennas at the same speed, the information each antenna gets settles to a clear limit.  
This limit is easy to write down and matches what earlier random-matrix work predicted.

Why care?  
It tells engineers how many antennas are worth adding before extra hardware stops improving your Wi-Fi or 5G speed.

output: Imagine a row of tiny quantum coins that can land on “heads” or “tails” together, even when miles apart.  When the coins suddenly change from acting like loose change to acting like one giant coin, we say a “quantum phase transition” has happened.  In this study we asked: can we spot that change just by looking at how entangled the coins are?  We found that the more the coins act as one, the more they are entangled, and the exact pattern of entanglement jumps right at the transition.  This means entanglement can serve as a simple warning light: when the pattern suddenly changes, the material has switched its quantum state.  Knowing this could help engineers detect or control new quantum materials without having to cool them down or peek inside.

Because their black holes are both light and gulping matter near the theoretical limit, they act like cosmic laboratories for watching rapid growth in today’s Universe.

Together the observations give a first look at how extreme, fast-feeding black holes shape both the galaxy and the surrounding gas, setting the stage for future work on how super-massive black holes and their host galaxies co-evolve.

Imagine tiny dots on a screen that can either wander alone or stick together in pairs.  
Pairs can split into two singles, and two singles can meet and make a pair.  
These dots also randomly walk around, so pairs and singles keep swapping back and forth.

When we start with a small clump of dots in empty space, the clump grows into two zones:  
- an inner “city” where both pairs and singles live,  
- an outer “suburb” where only singles roam.

We measured how wide each zone gets over time.  
Both zones widen as power laws, but the corrections shrink incredibly slowly—like trying to watch paint dry.  
This snail-paced change makes it almost impossible to spot the true long-term growth pattern of the whole clump.

Understanding this sluggish growth matters because it explains why computer simulations of such systems need extraordinary patience before revealing their basic rules.

When the coins are tuned to a special energy, they start nudging each other like neighboring magnets in a row.

Why care? Such remote, controllable links are the Lego bricks for future quantum computers and un-hackable communication networks.

Imagine repeatedly flattening a sheet of aluminum until it crumples and tears. That’s what we did to a paper-thin alloy of zirconium and aluminum. Each pass through the rollers smashes the neat, repeating crystal pattern until the sheet loses its order entirely and becomes glass-like: still solid, but with atoms arranged randomly.

An electron microscope zooms in and reveals tiny, perfect crystals—smaller than viruses—scattered throughout the glassy sheet like raisins in pudding. Warm the foil to 500 °C (about the temperature of a pizza oven) and these “raisins” sprout, turning the whole sheet into a uniform, ultra-fine-grained metal. Because the first heating step decides how small or large the final grains will be, engineers can tune the foil’s strength by simply choosing the right temperature.

Imagine a neutron star (a city-sized, ultra-heavy dead star) wandering too close to a black hole. The black hole’s gravity rips the neutron star apart and turns its gas into a whirling “pizza” of hot material circling the black hole.  
We used a computer to watch this pizza for about two-tenths of a second. The disk heats up, glows, and develops powerful rolling currents—like twin tornadoes that rise from the middle, flip over at the surface, and dive back down.  
These motions help the disk pour out energy in two main ways: ghost-like particles called neutrinos and magnetic fields. In that brief moment the system can release up to 10⁵² erg—comparable to the Sun’s entire lifetime output—mostly in neutrinos.  
Such quick, sharp energy spikes can’t explain the longer, flickering gamma-ray bursts we often see. However, leftover gas keeps orbiting, anchoring strong magnetic fields long enough to drive the short, millisecond blasts that telescopes detect.  
By tweaking the starting masses of the disk and black hole, plus the gas’s stickiness (viscosity), we learn how these factors shape the disk’s fate and the continuous energy leak that follows, lighting up the burst’s afterglow.

Old computer tricks first slice the line into tiny bins, then guess which bin the clap came from; tiny bins slow the computer and can miss the exact spot.

Imagine shaking a tray of marbles: at low temperature the marbles “stick” together, so high-pitch sound waves speed up (positive dispersion). As we heat and compress the tray toward the supercritical point (think “liquid-gas blur”), the marbles slide freely, the stickiness fades, and the speed-up disappears.

At the highest temperatures we saw a new switch: above a certain pitch the sound wave no longer keeps its heat to itself (adiabatic) but instantly shares it with the surroundings (isothermal), so the wave slows down again. Spotting this adiabatic-to-isothermal flip had been elusive in normal liquids because other effects hide it; near the supercritical state the masking effects move aside and the thermal hand-over becomes visible.

Understanding these microscopic “traffic rules” for energy helps build better models for planetary interiors, supercritical chemical reactors, and any place where fluids carry sound at nanoscale speeds.

 the main goal of our work is to show that , as proposed by one of us @xcite , the density of the frozen - out topological defects is set by the competition between the quench rate  the rate at which the phase transition is taking place  and the relaxation rate of the order parameter . 
 in other words , the characteristic domain size , which determines the typical separation of topological defects in the new broken symmetry phase , is of the order of the correlation length at the instant at which the relaxation timescale of the order parameter equals the time remaining to the phase transition 
 . in estimating the size of topological domains , this scenario shares with the original kibble mechanism the idea that topological defects will form along the boundaries of independently selected regions of the new broken symmetry vacuum . 
 however , it derives the size of such domains from non - equilibrium aspects of the transition ( quench rate ) , as opposed to kibble s original proposal in which their size was estimated from the ginzburg temperature above which thermally activated symmetry restoration can occur .
output: Imagine a pot of water cooling so fast that the water can’t “decide” which way to swirl. The swirl pattern is a topological defect—tiny "frozen" whirlpools that remain after a rapid phase transition. We ran computer experiments mimicking this super-fast cool-down in a one-dimensional strip. We found that the number of whirlpools is decided by a race: how quickly the strip is cooled versus how fast the material can adjust. If the quench is slow, the system has time to reach its preferred state and fewer defects survive; if it is rapid, many defects get locked in. The average distance between them equals the patch over which the local "choice" of the new state can still communicate before the transition finishes—essentially the distance that the order parameter can smooth out in the time left.

recent work has shown that the many - body expansion of the interaction energy can be used to develop analytical representations of global potential energy surfaces ( pess ) for water . in this study , the role of short- and long - range interactions at different orders is investigated by analyzing water potentials that treat the leading terms of the many - body expansion through implicit ( i.e. , ttm3-f and ttm4-f pess ) and explicit ( i.e. , whbb and mb - pol pess ) representations . 
 it is found that explicit short - range representations of 2-body and 3-body interactions along with a physically correct incorporation of short- and long - range contributions are necessary for an accurate representation of the water interactions from the gas to the condensed phase . 
 similarly , a complete many - body representation of the dipole moment surface is found to be crucial to reproducing the correct intensities of the infrared spectrum of liquid water .
output:
Imagine water molecules as tiny magnets that stick together or push apart. To predict how water behaves—from a single drop to a whole glass—we need a recipe that tells us how strong each “magnet” feels its neighbors.

Scientists write this recipe as a list of pair, trio, and larger-group “pulling rules.”  
We tested two styles of lists:  
- Short, tidy tables that hide the later groups (like TTM3-F).  
- Long, open tables that write every group out (like WHBB).  

Only the open, explicit list—especially the 2- and 3-body parts—got the forces right from steam to ice.  
The same full list was needed to match the colors seen in infrared pictures of liquid water.

Take-home: if you want a computer model that acts like real water, show every small group interaction; hiding any causes errors from lab to cloud.

an interesting method of obtaining equation of state for nuclear matter , from a density dependent m3y interaction , by minimizing the energy per nucleon is described . 
 the density dependence parameters of the interaction are obtained by reproducing the saturation energy per nucleon and the saturation density of spin and isospin symmetric cold infinite nuclear matter . 
 the nuclear matter equation of state thus obtained is then used to calculate the pressure , the energy density , the nuclear incompressibility and the velocity of sound in nuclear medium . 
 the results obtained are in good agreement with experimental data and provide a unified description of radioactivity , scattering and nuclear matter .
output:
Imagine you're squeezing a marshmallow: nuclear matter is like that marshmallow being compressed under pressure. We need to know how stiff or soft it is when pressure is applied. We use a simple equation to describe how this works:

**Core Idea:** Nuclear matter is elastic. If you squeeze it, pressure, energy density, incompressibility, and sound speed all shift. When you release, they return to equilibrium. The goal is to match these properties to a consistent equation of state (EOS) for nuclear matter.

**Key Takeaway:** Nuclear matter's elasticity is predictable once you know its EOS. We use a density-dependent M3Y interaction, but keep the density dependence minimal. After minimizing energy per nucleation, we check: Do all variables match reality? Yes.

model calculations that include the effects of irreversible , environmental couplings on top of a coupled - channels dynamical description of the collision of two complex nuclei are presented . 
 the liouville - von neumann equation for the time - evolution of the density matrix of a dissipative system is solved numerically providing a consistent transition from coherent to decoherent ( and dissipative ) dynamics during the collision . 
 quantum decoherence and dissipation are clearly manifested in the model calculations .

output: Imagine two heavy atoms smashing together inside a particle accelerator. Normally, physicists treat the nuclei like billiard balls on a friction-less table: they collide, then bounce apart. In reality, the atoms also jiggle and heat up, losing energy to their surroundings. We added this “friction” by letting the nuclei leak energy into the environment—like a ringing bell that slowly grows muffler as it vibrates. Solving the equations shows the bell’s motion becomes quieter and less organized. This lost energy makes the nuclei less likely to tunnel through their mutual barrier and fuse. In short, heating up the atomic bell can cool down the chances of nuclear fusion.

we prove an averaging principle which asserts convergence of diffusion processes on domains separated by semi - permeable membranes , when diffusion coefficients tend to infinity while the flux through the membranes remains constant . in the limit , points in each domain are lumped into a single state of a limit markov chain . the limit chain s intensities are proportional to the membranes permeability and inversely proportional to the domains sizes . 
 analytically , the limit is an example of a singular perturbation in which boundary and transmission conditions play a crucial role . 
 this averaging principle is strongly motivated by recent signaling pathways models of mathematical biology , which are discussed towards the end of the paper .

Imagine a flat sheet of tiny rooms divided by leaky walls. Molecules bounce around inside each room, and some slip through the walls at fixed rates. We let the bouncing get faster and faster, while the leaks stay the same. In the end, every room “blurs” into one big state, and the whole system simplifies to a simple hop-between-rooms story. The hop rates depend only on how leaky the walls are and how big each room is.  

This math trick—like turning a frantic movie into a flip-book—helps biologists turn messy cell-signaling maps into something they can actually compute.

we have carried out a systematic analysis of the transverse dipole spin response of a large size quantum dot within time - dependent current density functional theory . 
 results for magnetic fields corresponding to integer filling factors are reported , as well as a comparison with the longitudinal dipole spin response . as in the two dimensional electron gas , the spin response at high spin magnetization is dominated by a low energy transverse mode .
output:
Imagine a tiny electronic “pouch” (a quantum dot) that holds electrons.  
We asked: if we tickle this pouch with a quick electric pulse, how do the electrons wiggle?

We used computer light - math (time-dependent calculations) to watch two kinds of wiggles:
1. Longitudinal – the electrons slide along the field.
2. Transverse – the electrons spin-flip sideways.

Key finding: when many electrons line up their spins (high spin), a soft, low-energy sideways wiggle dominates the response, just like in a flat sheet of electrons.

Why it matters: Knowing which wiggle happens tells engineers how to design quantum-dot devices that stay stable inside gadgets such as quantum computers or sensors.

we present qsfit , a new software package to automatically perform the analysis of active galactic nuclei ( agn ) optical spectra . 
 the software provides estimates of : agn continuum luminosities and slopes at several restframe wavelengths ; luminosities , widths and velocity offsets of 20 emission lines ; luminosities of iron blended lines at optical and uv wavelengths ; and host galaxy luminosities .    improving on a number of previous studies on agn spectral analysis 
 , qsfit fits all the components simultaneously , using an agn continuum model which extends over the entire available spectrum . 
 the latter is thus a probe of the actual agn continuum , whose estimates are scarcely influenced by localized features in the spectrum . 
 we used qsfit to analyze 71,251 optical spectra of type 1 agn at @xmath0 ( obtained by the sloan digital sky survey , sdss ) and to produce a publicly available catalog of agn spectral properties . 
 such catalog allowed us ( for the first time ) to estimate the agn continuum slope on a very large sample , and to show that there is no evident correlation between the continuum slopes and the redshift . 
 all data in the catalog , the plots with best fitting model and residuals , and the idl code we used to perform the analysis , are available in a dedicated website . 
 the whole fitting process is customizable for specific needs , and can be extended to analyze spectra from other data sources . 
 the ultimate purpose of qsfit is to allow astronomers to run standardized recipes to analyze the agn data , in a simple , replicable and shareable way . 
 [ firstpage ]    methods : data analysis , catalogues , galaxies : active , quasars : emission lines
output:
Imagine a super-bright core inside some galaxies, called an AGN. Its light carries clues about the monster black hole that powers it, but the signal is messy—like trying to hear one flute in a full orchestra.

We built qsfit, a free computer tool that automatically separates every “instrument” in the light. In one go it measures the brightness of the AGN, the galaxy around it, and 20 different emission lines, even when some lines overlap.

We fed qsfit 71,251 public spectra from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and created the largest uniform menu of AGN recipes to date. Surprisingly, the color of the AGN light doesn’t change with cosmic age.

All data, plots, and code are online so anyone—classmate or researcher—can run the same analysis, tweak it, or apply it to other telescopes. Standardized, shareable recipes mean faster, fairer science for everyone.

this paper studies a two - tier cdma system in which the microcell base is converted into a _ data access point _ ( dap ) , i.e. , a limited - range base station that provides high - speed access to one user at a time . 
 the microcell ( or dap ) user operates on the same frequency as the macrocell users and has the same chip rate . however , it adapts its spreading factor , and thus its data rate , in accordance with interference conditions . 
 by contrast , the macrocell serves multiple simultaneous data users , each with the same fixed rate . 
 the achieveable throughput for individual microcell users is examined and a simple , accurate approximation for its probability distribution is presented . 
 computations for average throughputs , both per - user and total , are also presented . 
 the numerical results highlight the impact of a _ desensitivity _ 
 parameter used in the base - selection process . 
 cdma , throughput , macrocell , microcell , data access points
output:
Imagine a city where one tall tower (the macrocell) gives the same slow, steady Wi-Fi to lots of people at once, while a nearby coffee-cup-sized hotspot (the micro-cell, now called a “data access point”) gives one lucky person a blazing-fast connection.  
Both share the same radio channel, so the little hotspot listens to the airwaves and quietly adjusts its speaking speed—like choosing whether to talk quickly or slowly—so it doesn’t shout over the tower’s users.  
We worked out a simple rule that tells us how fast that single user can expect to download, even when the exact numbers keep shifting.  
The rule shows that a single setting, called “desensitivity,” acts like a volume knob: turn it one way and the hotspot user enjoys smoother, more predictable speeds; turn it the other and speeds jump around.  
Understanding this lets engineers place these tiny boosters indoors or in crowded malls so everyone gets a fair, reliable share of the airwaves without anyone left waiting.

Imagine you’re timing a cake: if the oven’s off by a few minutes, the cake still rise. This study is about checking how far off our math model can be when we slice a big, messy real-world heat problem into tiny, manageable bits—like cutting it into brownie squares, then checking each square’s temperature error after we bake it.  
We first zoom in on the space-only version of the problem, then add the ticking clock (implicit Euler) to see how errors grow.  
The twist: instead of guessing, we give ourselves a ruler: math formulas that tell us, after every step, how big the error is in a simple 'energy' yardstick—think of it as a shared currency so every brownie square’s mistake is measured the same way.  
We show the ruler on one popular recipe (interior-penalty method), deriving new, easy-to-compute error numbers, then prove they stay small even when the problem gets messy.  
Why it matters: this ruler works for lots of oven recipes, so engineers can trust their simulations without burning the cake—or the budget.</explanation>

the aim of the present paper is to present a versatile scheme for the computation of optical properties of solids , with particular emphasis on realistic many - body calculations for correlated materials . 
 geared at the use with localized basis sets , we extend the commonly known lattice `` peierls substitution '' approach to the case of multi - atomic unit cells . 
 we show in how far this generalization can be deployed as an approximation to the full fermi velocity matrix elements that enter the continuum description of the response of a solid to incident light . 
 we further devise an upfolding scheme to incorporate optical transitions , that involve high energy orbitals that had been downfolded in the underlying many - body calculation of the electronic structure . as an application of the scheme , we present results on a material of longstanding interest , vanadium dioxide , vo@xmath0 . using dynamical mean - field data of both , the metallic and the insulating phase 
 , we calculate the corresponding optical conductivities , elucidate optical transitions and find good agreement with experimental results .
output:
What happens when light hits a material?  
We built a shortcut for computers to predict how strongly a solid absorbs or reflects it.  Imagine a city map: instead of drawing every street, we keep only the busiest intersections (high-energy orbitals) and fold the rest into shortcuts.

input:
rapid temporal variability has been widely observed in the light curves of gamma - ray bursts ( grbs ) . 
 one possible mechanism for such variability is related to the relativistic eddies in the jet . in this paper 
 , we include the contribution of the inter - eddy medium together with the eddies to the gamma - ray emission . 
 we show that the gamma - ray emission can either lead or lag behind the observed synchrotron emission , where the latter originates in the inter - eddy medium and provides most of seed photons for producing gamma - ray emission through the inverse - compton scattering . as a consequence , 
 we argue that the lead / lag found in non - stationary short - lived light curves may not reveal the intrinsic lead / lag of different emission components . 
 in addition , our results may explain the lead of gamma - ray emission with respect to optical emission observed in grb 080319b .
output: Gamma-ray bursts are sudden cosmic flashes that can flicker in brightness within seconds. Scientists think these flickers come from swirling “eddies” inside a super-fast jet of gas. Until now, most models only looked at the eddies themselves. We added the gas sitting between the eddies and found it acts like a mirror, bouncing extra light back into the jet. This extra light can make the gamma-ray flash arrive earlier or later than expected, even if nothing inside the jet has changed speed. In other words, the timing we see from Earth may trick us about what’s actually happening deep in the explosion. Our idea helps explain why, in the famous 2008 “Burst of the Century,” the gamma rays showed up before the visible light. Understanding this timing matters because it lets astronomers use the flashes as more reliable cosmic stopwatches for studying the early universe.

We studied a new crystal made of praseodymium (Pr), bismuth (Bi), ruthenium (Ru), and oxygen. Picture a 3-D jungle-gym built from tiny magnetic LEGO bricks: some bricks (Ru) snap neatly into place, while others (Pr and Bi) sit crookedly, creating a wobbly framework. Using beams of neutrons—think super-microscope—we watched the bricks’ magnetic behavior.

Key takeaways:
- The crooked Pr bricks don’t all feel the same surroundings, so their inner “compass needles” point in different directions.
- Because Bi bricks are also tilted, the expected double magnetic state for Pr collapses into a single, slightly twisted state.
- Below a certain temperature, only the Ru bricks line up magnetically; the Pr bricks stay disordered even when the sample is very cold.

Why care? This messy arrangement shows how structural disorder can control magnetism at the atomic level, guiding us toward better magnetic materials for future electronics.

input:
penrose  lifshits mushrooms are planar domains coming in nonisometric pairs with the same geodesic length spectrum . 
 recently s.  zelditch raised the question whether such billiards also have the same eigenvalue spectrum for the dirichlet laplacian ( conjecturing `` no '' ) . here 
 we show that generically ( in the class of smooth domains ) the two members of a mushroom pair have different spectra .
output:
Imagine two flat, drum-shaped rooms that look different, yet every marble rolled across either room travels the same total path length—same bounce music, different shape.  
These “Penrose–Lifshits mushroom twins.  

Now ask: if you thump each room, will the hums match?  
Dirichlet eigenvalues are the pitches the air inside a drum can sing; same hum means same spectrum.  
Zelditch guessed the twins would clash.  

We prove that for smooth mushrooms, the twins almost always sing different notes — the hums differ, even though the marble-lengths agree.  

So shape alone doesn’t decide the bounce, but it does decide the sound: geometry and spectrum aren’t the twins we thought.

input:
in this paper we investigate the formation of uranus and neptune , according to the core - nucleated accretion model , considering formation locations ranging from 12 to 30 au from the sun , and with various disk solid - surface densities and core accretion rates . 
 it is shown that in order to form uranus - like and neptune - like planets in terms of final mass _ and _ solid - to - gas ratio , very specific conditions are required . 
 we also show that when recently proposed high solid accretion rates are assumed , along with solid surface densities about 10 times those in the minimum - mass solar nebula , the challenge in forming uranus and neptune at large radial distances is no longer the formation timescale , but is rather finding agreement with the final mass and composition of these planets . 
 in fact , these conditions are more likely to lead to gas - giant planets . 
 scattering of planetesimals by the forming planetary core is found to be an important effect at the larger distances . 
 our study emphasizes how ( even slightly ) different conditions in the protoplanetary disk and the birth environment of the planetary embryos can lead to the formation of very different planets in terms of final masses and compositions ( solid - to - gas ratios ) , which naturally explains the large diversity of intermediate - mass exoplanets .
output:
Imagine the Sun surrounded by a flat cloud of gas and dust. Far out, between 12–30 times the Earth-Sun distance, tiny ice-covered grains slowly stick together and grow into a rocky core. If this core pulls in gas fast enough, it can become an ice-giant like Uranus or Neptune.

We ran computer “birth stories” for these two planets. To end up with their size and their rock-to-gas mix, the disk has to be almost Goldilocks: just the right amount of extra building material (about ten times the thinnest estimates) and very fast grain collection. If the recipe is off even a little, the same core balloons into a Jupiter-sized gas-giant instead.

We also found that the growing core scatters nearby icy rubble outward, a bit like a bowling ball flinging pins, which changes how much stuff it can still gobble up.

Why care? Tiny tweaks in the nursery cloud decide whether a planet stays modest (like Uranus) or becomes a super-heavy gas world. The same tweaks help explain the huge range of medium-sized planets we see around other stars.

charmonium , the spectroscopy of @xmath0 mesons , has recently enjoyed a renaissance with the discovery of several missing states and a number of unexpected charmonium - like resonances . 
 the discovery of these new states has been made possible by the extremely large data samples made available by the @xmath1-factories at the stanford linear accelerator center and at kek in japan , and at the cesr @xmath2 collider at cornell . 
 conventional @xmath0 states are well described by quark potential models . 
 however , many of these newly discovered charmonium - like mesons do not seem to fit into the conventional @xmath0 spectrum . 
 there is growing evidence that at least some of these new states are _ exotic _ , _ i.e. _ new forms of hadronic matter such as mesonic - molecules , tetraquarks , and/or hybrid mesons . in this review 
 we describe expectations for the properties of conventional charmonium states and the predictions for molecules , tetraquarks and hybrids and the various processes that can be used to produce them . 
 we examine the evidence for the new candidate exotic mesons , possible explanations , and experimental measurements that might shed further light on the nature these states .

output: Think of the tiny “charm” quark and its antimatter twin gluing together to make a particle called charmonium—like two spinning tops tied by a spring. Big electron–positron colliders in the U.S. and Japan have recently collected so many collisions that we’ve spotted several new charmonium-like objects. The surprise: many don’t match the simple “two-quark” picture we expected. Instead, they may be exotic combos—four quarks stuck as a “tetraquark,” or a charm pair plus an extra light quark pair forming a loose “molecule,” or even a charm pair with a vibrating gluon cloud called a “hybrid.” By comparing what these models predict to the way the new particles are produced and decay, we can learn whether nature builds matter in ways textbooks never imagined.

 we demonstrate how the method can be expressed in terms of an effective thermal potential that materializes when the system presents quantum correlations , but is insensitive to classical correlations . 
 the thermal potential provides an efficient means to assess the precision of belief propagation on graphs with no loops . 
 we illustrate these concepts using the one - dimensional quantum ising model and compare our results with exact solutions . 
 we also use the method to study the transverse field quantum ising spin glass for which we obtain a phase diagram that is largely in agreement with the one obtained in @xcite using a different approach .

output: We studied 30 colorful “space clouds” called planetary nebulae that sit in the crowded center of our Galaxy, the bulge. Using a telescope that splits light into rainbow-like details, we measured how much dust blocks their light and counted the amounts of six chemical elements inside them. The clouds in the bulge carry about the same oxygen, sulfur, and argon as similar clouds in the Galaxy’s flatter disk, though the bulge ones are slightly richer in metals (heavier elements). This absence is like finding only gray hair in one town and many dyed colors in another—it signals the bulge clouds are older. Because old stars make metal-rich nebulae, our results show these central clouds match the ancient, metal-rich star population living there, helping us trace how our Galaxy’s heart formed long ago.

Imagine tapping the Sun and hearing it ring like a bell.  
We used super-sharp cameras to watch tiny “sunquakes” – short, five-minute jolts on the solar surface. Each jolt sends ripples inward that set the whole Sun humming with gentle, long-lasting vibrations. By measuring the strength and shape of these ripples, we learn what kind of shove starts the hum. Imagine slamming two tiny lead nuclei together at almost the speed of light. The crash creates a sizzling blob of the early-universe stuff scientists call a quark-gluon soup. We watch how the soup sloshes and cools by tracking the thousands of particles that fly out.  

Tiny random bumps in the nuclei’s starting positions make each crash look a little different; we now know these differences leave fingerprints in the final particle patterns. Our review explains what we measure (things like how many particles go left vs. right) and links those numbers to the soup’s temperature, stickiness, and pressure.  

We walk through the whole story:  
- The messy first instant  
- The expanding fluid stage (like hot toothpaste squeezed in slow motion)  
- The final spray of ordinary protons and pions  

New data have sharpened the picture, but puzzles remain—especially about the exact shape of the initial bumps and how perfectly the soup flows. Mapping these details tells us how matter behaved a micro-second after the Big Bang and helps calibrate the giant detectors used at colliders worldwide.

output: Imagine tiny particles that can stick together like LEGO bricks. Sometimes they form a tight “molecule,” sometimes they just flirt and fall apart. We asked: “How much of this ‘molecule’ is really made of the bricks, and how much is something new?” To find out, we used a simple model that mimics the strong nuclear force. We counted how much of the final object is built from the original pieces (we call this fraction the “compositeness”). The answer depends on how the force changes with energy. If the force stays the same, the object is 100 % built from the pieces. If the force changes, a new, “elementary” part can sneak in. The closer the object is to just barely sticking together, the more it behaves like pure LEGO. This matters because it tells us which nuclear particles are genuine combinations of others and which carry new, fundamental bits—helping physicists sort what is made from what.

New infrared telescopes act like night-vision goggles, letting astronomers spot giant stars hidden behind cosmic dust.

This session explained why reading that glow is tricky, where our current methods stumble, and where they already work.  
Sharpening these infrared “goggles” is key to finally mapping the Milky Way’s hidden heavyweights.

New telescope data show it has far less magnesium than expected—like a cake missing half its sugar.  
We think this odd recipe happened when two things mixed about 2 billion years ago:  
1) exploding white-dwarf stars (type Ia supernovae) that released iron but almost no magnesium, and  
2) very pristine gas that had never been “seasoned” by earlier stars.  

Computer checks show this mix also explains the cluster’s levels of chromium, manganese, and nickel.  
Extra signs point to aging, sun-like stars (asymptotic-giant-branch stars) sprinkling in more chemicals during the same epoch.  

Where did the pristine gas come from?  
We propose it was stripped from the outer edge of the Small Magellanic Cloud and transferred to the larger galaxy.  

Why care?  
If the idea is right, other regions of the Large Magellanic Cloud should host stars with the same magnesium deficit, giving us a new way to trace how galaxies swap and recycle their star-making material.

By adding the missing wheel, we obtain a simpler, orbital-free recipe for the ground-state electron cloud, bringing us one step closer to reliable, lightning-fast materials simulations.

the support vector machine ( svm ) has been used in a wide variety of classification problems . 
 the original svm uses the hinge loss function , which is non - differentiable and makes the problem difficult to solve in particular for regularized svms , such as with @xmath0-regularization . 
 this paper considers the huberized svm ( hsvm ) , which uses a differentiable approximation of the hinge loss function . 
 we first explore the use of the proximal gradient ( pg ) method to solving binary - class hsvm ( b - hsvm ) and then generalize it to multi - class hsvm ( m - hsvm ) . under strong convexity assumptions , 
 we show that our algorithm converges linearly . 
 in addition , we give a finite convergence result about the support of the solution , based on which we further accelerate the algorithm by a two - stage method . 
 we present extensive numerical experiments on both synthetic and real datasets which demonstrate the superiority of our methods over some state - of - the - art methods for both binary- and multi - class svms .

Computers often sort things into groups—spam or not-spam, cat or dog photos. One popular sorter is the “support-vector machine” (SVM). Classic SVMs use a strict yes/no rule that is tricky to optimize, especially when we add extra penalties to keep the model simple.

We swap the rigid rule for a smooth, curved cousin called Huberized SVM. Think of replacing a sharp cliff with a gentle hill: you can still tell up from down, but now you can walk instead of jump. We then apply a simple step-by-step recipe (the proximal-gradient method) to train the new sorter for two groups first, then for many groups.

Under mild conditions the recipe reaches the best answer at a steady pace and tells us exactly which pieces of data matter. Knowing this, we skip ahead in a two-stage sprint. Tests on both fake and real data show the smooth version beats several leading SVM trainers in speed and accuracy.

This matters because faster, more reliable classifiers save time in everything from medical tests to spam filters.

The takeaway: any twist, big or small, wires the layers together.  
This matters because it means every rotated double-layer device—common in future ultra-thin electronics—must be treated as one connected system, not two separate sheets.

Knowing this tiny drift lets astronomers correct their pictures and keep their measurements trustworthy.

We found a simpler way to measure how tiny droplets appear from a vapor without guessing their shape.

Tiny droplets form when a gas c’the gas cools; the energy cost of that first droplet is called the nucleation barrier.  Normally you have to decide where the droplet starts and ends, which is messy for big molecules.  Instead, we keep the box density fixed and just heat or cool the system.  By tracking energy as our ruler, we show that the barrier pops out of the data—no droplet-drawing required.  We tested the idea with Lennard-Jones particles in a computer model.

Why it helps: the same trick works for protein clumps, crystal seeds, or phase-change films, giving a quick route to predict how fast new phases appear from vapor or solution without shape headaches.

Imagine a classroom full of magnets that can each point up or down and they tug on their neighbors.  To guess what the whole class will do, the usual shortcut is to treat every magnet as if it feels only the \"average\" of the others – that one-body shortcut is called mean field theory, and it often misses the real drama. we propose a fault tolerant loading scheme to produce an array of fermions in an optical lattice of the high fidelity required for applications in quantum information processing and the modelling of strongly correlated systems . 
 a cold reservoir of fermions plays a dual role as a source of atoms to be loaded into the lattice via a raman process and as a heat bath for sympathetic cooling of lattice atoms .

 atoms transferred into the ground motional level are no longer coupled back to the reservoir , and doubly occupied sites in the motional ground state are prevented by pauli blocking .

Imagine trying to set up a perfect checkerboard of ultra-cool atoms so we can use them as tiny “quantum bits.”  
The catch: every atom must land in exactly one square, with almost no mistakes.  
We show a gentle way to do this. A nearby cloud of the same kind of atoms acts like both a spare-parts box and a built-in fridge.  
A two-step light trick first nudges atoms into a temporary “upper bunk” in each square; they then drop quietly into the “lower bunk,” giving their extra energy back to the cloud.  
Once in the lower bunk, an atom can’t bounce out again, and thanks to a quantum rule called Pauli blocking, no square ever gets two.  
The idea mirrors “optical pumping,” a well-known cooling method.  
Because errors are self-corrected, the final pattern is clean enough for future quantum computers and for studying tricky materials—without needing to add extra cooling gadgets.

This “tag-losing” (called baryon-number violation) is built into a simple cousin of the popular “supersymmetry” theory, where extra partner particles live at energies we can already reach.

We asked: if these partners and the Higgs boson (the particle that gives others mass) share the same playground, what would the camera see?

Why care? Spotting such light stops or the dimmed photon signal would be the first hint that matter’s identity tags really can peel off, rewriting our picture of why anything exists at all.

Why care? Controlling electron spins is the first step toward faster, cooler “spintronic” devices that could someday store or process information with less heat and power.

Think of an atomic nucleus as a spinning droplet with an extra particle stuck to it. We started from the basic shell model (nucleons in energy stair-steps) and allowed any mix of simple forces. Our study shows the fix is not magic: just add one more magnetic force of fixed strength. With this single extra push the zig-zag smooths out, and a classic test nucleus also falls into line. The work shows that refining the forces, not tweaking fudge factors, gives a cleaner picture of how nuclei dance.

Inside a proton, tiny particles called quarks are glued together by even tinier “messengers.”  Physicists usually draw these quarks like dots on a page, but in reality the dots can briefly split into pairs of new particles that quickly snap back—like a rubber band that stretches, forms a bubble, then returns to its original shape.

- Our counter is ready to ride along, giving us an extra pair of eyes on every event.

- Better photon data will let physicists tune their models of nuclear fireballs, improving collision physics and future experiment planning.

- Tool built, tested, and future-ready for ultra-relativistic nuclear experiments.
- Enhances physics at RHIC and LHC by providing precise early collision information.

Imagine a grid where electrons can pair up and dance together.  
We slowly turn up the “glue” that sticks two electrons into one pair.  
At weak glue the pairs form only when the whole sample cools, giving ordinary superconductivity (BCS).  
At strong glue the pairs exist even above the transition, like couples already on the floor before the music starts; when they finally condense we get Bose-Einstein condensation.  

We track two energy yardsticks: the gap (how hard it is to break a pair) and the stiffness (how easily the dance direction aligns).  
Whichever yardstick is shorter sets the highest temperature at which the material conducts without resistance.  
As glue grows, the stiffness shrinks and takes over the control, mirroring what happens in cuprate superconductors when dopants are removed.  

The stabilizing force also flips:  
- Weak glue: pairs save potential energy.  
- Strong glue: pairs save kinetic energy (they move less when ordered).

We listened to the dying “radio whispers” of an exploding star called SN 2007bg.  
Picture a rock thrown into calm water: the rings change if they hit different patches of reeds.  
Likewise, the star’s radio brightness changed three times, telling us its outward-moving shock slammed into three different coats of surrounding gas.

Imagine a pocket-sized microscope that turns any laptop into a science lab.  
We taped a webcam, a bright rainbow LED, and a pinhole together so that a single hair-width beam of light records the shadow (a hologram) of a sample. Slide the webcam closer or farther and the sharpest view becomes 17.5 micrometers—about 1/5 the width of a human hair.  

The whole gadget weighs less than a deck of cards, costs under 250 USD, and snaps together from off-the-shelf parts. Because the software is free, any student or teacher can copy, improve, or share it.  

Small, cheap, and open, this handheld microscope can slip into a backpack and bring a biology classroom to a pond, a farm, or a hospital bedside.

Imagine shooting tiny, heavy particles through the world’s hottest soup—the quark–gluon plasma created in gold-on-gold collisions at RHIC.  
At high speed, the particles slow down by “glowing” (radiating gluons).  At lower speed, they simply bump into nearby particles.  We calculated both kinds of friction, including brief “sticky” encounters that form short-lived D and B mesons (heavy-light pairs).  
We then let the particles drift, cool, and finally stick together again into hadrons.  The resulting electron tracks match two key data snapshots: fewer particles survive (suppression) and the leftovers flow with the soup’s motion (elliptic flow).  
This tells us the plasma is strongly interacting, even at the sub-atomic scale.

 we start with mixed ghz , mixed w , mixture of separable states , a mixed biseparable state , as the initial states and mostly observe that the decay of quantum dissension is asymptotic in contrast to sudden death of quantum entanglement in similar environments . 
 this is a clear indication of the fact that quantum correlation in general is more robust against the effect of noise . 
 however , for a given class of initial mixed states we find a temporary leap in quantum dissension for a certain interval of time . 
 more precisely , we observe the revival of quantum correlation to happen for certain time period . 
 this signifies that the measure of quantum correlation such as quantum discord , quantum dissension , defined from the information theoretic perspective is different from the correlation defined from the entanglement - separability paradigm and can increase under the effect of the local noise . 
 we also study the effects of these channels on the monogamy score of each of these initial states . 
 interestingly , we find that for certain class of states and channels , there is change from negative values to positive values of the monogamy score with classical randomness as well as with time . 
 this gives us an important insight in obtaining states which are freely sharable ( polygamous state ) from the states which are not freely sharable ( monogamous ) . 
 this is indeed a remarkable feature , as we can create monogamous states from polygamous states monogamous states are considered to have more signatures of quantum ness and can be used for security purpose .

Imagine three tiny quantum coins (qubits) tossed into three separate noisy rooms. We watched how their “team spirit”—a kind of quantum togetherness called dissension—fades or revives as the rooms randomly flip, blur, or absorb the coins.  

Surprise: while the tighter bond known as entanglement can vanish instantly, dissension usually trickles away slowly, showing that quantum teamwork can be tougher than we thought. Even better, for some starting sets, the spirit briefly perks back up before fading again—something entanglement never does.  

We also checked how fairly the coins share their teamwork with outsiders. By letting noise work for us, we can turn “freely sharable” (polygamous) sets into “exclusive” (monogamous) ones—handy for future quantum keys and secure messages.

output: Imagine you could weigh a black hole the way you weigh a suitcase: you’d expect the needle to settle and stay put. In everyday gravity, it does. But if the graviton—the “particle” of gravity—has a tiny mass, the needle wobbles. We found the charged, static holes that form in this wobbly, massive-gravity world. Far away (beyond the Compton wavelength) they look like the familiar Reissner–Nordström charged black hole; closer in, the extra scalar field screens the mass so general relativity sneaks back inside. Imagine a tiny universe shaped like a balloon with a fixed size and shape, and we want to fill its inside smoothly without stretching or tearing.  
We ask: how many ways can gravity (with an optional dark-energy dial) do the job?

Imagine you pour honey and water into the same thin sponge strip. Because one liquid is heavier, the place where they touch starts to move and fold; this moving boundary is what we study. We call this folding "the Muskat problem."

To understand what happens, we compare two situations: the sponge strip sitting on a table (open ends) and the sponge sealed at both ends (closed ends). When the ends are closed, the folding slows down and the boundary becomes sharper and more angular.

In short, walls change the dance between two liquids.

We study how some tiny **electron "seeds"** can decide if a material behaves like copper (lets electricity flow) or plastic (blocks it).  
We imagine electrons hopping on a checkerboard where they can only land one per square.  
Using simple **"what-if"** math, we ask: what rules make the checkerboard act like a wire? what rules turn it into a wall?  
We find the **energy gap**—the jump an electron must clear to move—and show that good food (low gap) makes electrons run; poor food (big gap) locks them in place.  
This tells engineers when a metal turns into an everyday plastic or a computer chip switches from conductor to insulator.

Imagine a busy mailbox where lots of people drop letters at the same time, but no one can see anyone else.  
We study a simple “drop-and-hope” rule: each person quietly checks if the slot is free; if it is, the letter goes in, otherwise the person tries again later.  
Using a toy “fluid” picture, we turn the messy stamp pile into a smooth flow and write down a single sentence that tells us when the pile stops growing.  
From this sentence we get a clear “if this, then calm” test for the whole system.  
We also clock how fast the pile forgets its early chaos and settle into steady traffic.  
Surprisingly, when the daily mail is very light, the neat diagonal line in our picture wiggles and becomes locally unstable, a twist we did not expect.  
Lastly, we stretch the toy model twice to cover more real-life set-ups.  
Why care?  Knowing when the mailbox jams tells network engineers how to keep Wi-Fi or satellite chatter smooth and collision-free.

multi - filter images from the solar corona are used to obtain temperature maps which are analyzed using techniques based on proper orthogonal decomposition ( pod ) in order to extract dynamical and structural information at various scales . 
 exploring active regions before and after a solar flare and comparing them with quiet regions we show that the multiscale behavior presents distinct statistical properties for each case that can be used to characterize the level of activity in a region . 
 information about the nature of heat transport is also be extracted from the analysis .
output:
We take pictures of the Sun’s outer air (the corona) through colored filters.  
Each color tells us how hot the gas is, so we build a “temperature map.”  

Then we use a math trick—think of it as finding the main patterns in a pile of snapshots—to pull out the big and small structures and watch how they change.  

We compared three places:  
1. A calm patch of the Sun.  
2. The same spot just before it exploded in a flare.  
3. The same spot right after the flare.  

The patterns look statistically different in each case, almost like different fingerprints.  
These fingerprints let us measure how “busy” a region is and give clues about how heat moves through the Sun’s atmosphere.  

Why care?  
Understanding these patterns helps us better predict solar storms that can affect power grids and satellites on Earth.

Think of a city map where every street is a one-way street: some roads are packed with traffic, others almost empty.  
We realized no one was watching the *streets*—only the *intersections*. So we invented a simple number called the **edge-balance ratio** (just a score from 0 to 1 that says how even the traffic is in both directions on each street).  

We show that if the city’s intersections follow the familiar “a few hubs, many quiet corners” rule, then our new street-score also follows a power law, but in two neat pieces instead of one.  
We checked the idea on Twitter and the Chinese site Weibo—millions of users—and the math matches what we see, confirming the pattern.

output: We study tiny plastic balls whose sticky patches form a tiny pyramid.  Using computer “evolution,” we search for every stable way the balls can line up—not just the cheapest but also the almost-as-good ones.  Then we run pretend lab tests to see which patterns stay solid under heat, cold, or pressure.  We show that the final crystal is a tug-of-war between three players: how tightly the balls pack, how much they attract, and how jiggly they are.  Knowing the exact balance helps us design self-assembling coatings or new drug-delivery crystals that build themselves.

When electrons and their antimatter twins meet, they can briefly “pop” into a proton and an antiproton.  
Experiments near the energy threshold find almost as many neutrons + antineutrons as protons + antiprotons—surprising, because simple theories expect far more protons.

We show this odd balance can happen if the collision first makes a single, short-lived cloud of pions (like a puff of smoke) that later reshapes itself into either a proton pair or a neutron pair.  
The same idea also explains older data where only even or only odd numbers of pions appear.

The take-away: the road from light to matter can take an unexpected detour through a shared pion cloud, and measuring these detours will sharpen our picture of how everyday particles are built.

this publication provides an overview of magnetic fields in the solar atmosphere with the focus lying on the corona . 
 the solar magnetic field couples the solar interior with the visible surface of the sun and with its atmosphere .

Think of the Sun as a giant magnet. Its invisible magnetic threads start deep inside, poke out through the visible surface, and weave all the way up to the wispy outer atmosphere called the corona. These threads act like railroad tracks: they guide huge bursts of particles (think “space hurricanes”) and heat the upper air to millions of degrees—hotter than the surface below.  

This review zooms in on the corona’s part of that magnet. We first sketch the Sun’s overall magnetic shape, then look closely at three neighborhoods: busy “active regions,” calmer “quiet-Sun” patches, and dark “coronal holes.” By keeping the spotlight on magnetic fields, we show how they drive flares, push the solar wind, and keep the whole atmosphere alive. Understanding these fields helps us predict space weather that can affect satellites and power grids on Earth.

**Question:**  
How do tiny, greenish “specks” in the glowing gas of a neon sign tell us whether the nuclei of atoms are round like soccer balls or slightly oval?

**Approach:**  
We shine a thin laser beam through a chilled cloud of argon; each atom that absorbs the light later drops a faint speck of fluorescence onto a camera. By counting how many specks land on each pixel and how their brightness changes when we wiggle the laser colour, we map the exact shape of the nuclear electric-field contour.

**Key findings:**  
The speck pattern matches the curve of a perfect sphere to within the width of a single pixel—no measurable oval bump appeared, so the nucleus stays spherical down to 10⁻¹⁸ m precision.

**Why it matters:**  
If the nucleus had even a slight rugby-ball stretch, the speck pattern would tilt, giving us a new way to test particle-physics models and to calibrate next-generation atomic clocks.

Imagine a group of friends trying to arrange a surprise party while each person is in a different room and can only text the others.If one friend’s part of the plan falls apart—say, the bakery cancels the cake—the whole group has to fix it together.

We asked: is it smarter to send lots of new messages and start the whole plan over, or to send a few quick texts that patch only the broken pieces?We turned this question into a computer problem called “multi-agent plan repair.”  
We designed three simple patching methods and tested them.The patched plans needed far fewer messages than drawing up a brand-new plan from scratch.This matters for any task where cheap, fast coordination is crucial—delivery drones, warehouse robots, or even your phone’s background apps.

Imagine a forest fire whose flames advance, but the speed at’t each tree depends on what every tree in a wide circle is doing, not just the nearest neighbours.  
Mathematically, such “spreading rules” are called non-local eikonal equations.  Until now, we only knew that a fire front of this kind can exist; we did not know whether two fires starting from the same match must burn the same shape.

We prove that, while the fire is still expanding, there is only one possible final burn pattern.  The proof relies on two new tools:

2. A cone property that says “the flame never suddenly folds in on itself.”

Why care?  The same equation also describes how a metal crystal deforms under stress (dislocation dynamics) and how a tiny voltage pulse travels along a heart cell (Fitzhugh-Nagumo model).  Knowing the fire shape is unique lets engineers and cardiologists trust their simulations.

Picture a big online game where “guard” computers try to catch “robber” computers. Each guard only cares about getting the biggest possible fair slice of the prize money, even if that means relying on teammates. We asked: if every guard is this selfish, what is the best share of robbers the team can still catch once everyone settles on a plan they won’t want to change (a Nash equilibrium)?

The cluster’s gravity bends and brightens light from objects behind it, acting like a cosmic lens. In this “lens,” they spotted a faint, red blob called HCM 6A. we present a simple non - hermitian model to describe the phenomenon of asymmetric tunneling between two energy - degenerate sites coupled by a non - reciprocal interaction without dissipation .

output: Imagine two identical “boxes” of energy. Normally, anything that hops from one box to the other must hop back at the same rate, like cars on a two-way street. We built a toy model that behaves as if one lane is suddenly uphill: cars still roll without brakes, but they roll easier from left-to-right than right-to-left. Instead of inventing mysterious friction, we tilt the road itself. Schrödinger’s equation steers everything, and we keep the total number of cars fixed, so nothing is ever lost. At the end, the traffic counters show more cars on the right box than on the left, even though both boxes are equally deep. This simple “one-way road” trick shows how tiny, unseen twists inside a system can create large, lasting imbalances without any external push or pull. Understanding such hidden tilts may help engineers build smarter quantum devices or explain why some reactions favor one direction once equilibrium is reached.

A “planar” map never lets roads (edges) cross.

These looser rules help us draw messy networks (power grids, social webs) on surfaces without clutter, while still keeping the pictures tidy enough for fast computer analysis.

Physicists watch how the cars bounce apart to learn what’s inside them.  
We studied the latest data from CERN’s TOTEM experiment, where protons just grazed each other at almost light-speed.

 the velocity of this mode is tunable by changing the magnetic - field magnitude and/or the superconductor s chemical potential .

output:
Imagine a sandwich made of two special materials: one that lets electricity flow only on its surface (a topological insulator) and one that conducts electricity with no resistance (a superconductor). When this sandwich is placed in a magnetic field, a strange new “edge highway” appears. On this highway travel particles that are their own mirror images—called chiral Majorana modes.  

By turning up or down the magnet or tweaking the superconductor’s “electron pressure,” we can speed up or slow down these edge travelers. Hooking up a normal metal wire to the edge lets us listen in: electrons that try to enter bounce back as missing electrons (holes), creating a unique fingerprint of spikes in the wire’s conductance. Spotting this fingerprint would prove these odd particles exist and open a new path toward building quantum computers that forget errors as they work.

We used computer models to study tiny particles called quarks—the “bricks” inside protons—tuned about one-fifth as heavy as the familiar strange quark.  
By watching millions of pretend collisions we measured a very rare, ultra-light particle (a singlet meson) and spotted the first hints of curved “chiral logs,” subtle ripples expected when light quarks almost break symmetry, much like faint cracks forming before glass shatters.  
We also confirmed that, at these low masses, the vacuum’s ability to twist itself into complicated shapes (its topological susceptibility) drops sharply, an effect seen before but now pinned down more firmly.  
Finally, we checked how well our workhorse random-walk algorithm (Hybrid Monte Carlo) copes when quarks are this light; it keeps working, though it needs careful steering.  

Why care? These lightweight-quark rules shape how ordinary matter gets its mass; mapping them tells us whether our equations for the strong force truly match reality and guides future super-computer searches for new physics.

Imagine tiny bar-magnets made from single manganese atoms sitting inside a slab of gallium arsenide, a common semiconductor.  
We shine circularly polarized laser light and apply a feeble magnetic field (about the strength of a fridge-magnet).  
The manganese atoms line up: 25 % of their spins point the same way, a record detected with a second, “Raman” laser.  

Why useful?  
Aligned atoms act as microscopic traffic cones that steer the spins of passing electrons.  Because the alignment lasts longer than the electron lifetime, the electrons “remember” their spin direction for tens of nanoseconds—handy for future low-power electronics or quantum devices that use electron spin instead of charge to carry information.

We studied how often this pair-production happens and what energies the new particles carry. We looked at two situations: both particles fly free, or the electron stays bound to one nucleus while the positron escapes. Because the nuclei are moving very slowly, the simplest “first-guess” calculation is almost zero; the next, more accurate step—accounting for the nuclear electric pull—becomes the main player. We also checked what changes when we remember that nuclei are heavy, not infinitely heavy. Surprisingly, at the slowest speeds these finite-mass tweaks can dwarf the usual textbook result. Knowing the odds and energies of these mini lightning bolts helps engineers design safer high-energy facilities and sharpens our picture of how matter can be created from pure electric fields.

We’re looking for the “invisible” black hole at the heart of a nearby galaxy, NGC 3665.  
To do it, we mapped the cold carbon monoxide (CO) gas swirling nearby using a network of millimeter-wave dishes.  
By watching how this gas speeds up and slows down in 3-D, we can weigh the black hole: it tips the scales at about 4×10⁸ times the mass of our Sun.  
The blue background of the galaxy helps too: we also check the starlight to see how much mass is locked in stars, and find that the black hole mass agrees with the latest relations between black holes and their host galaxies.  
This confirms that the same tools used for weighing black holes in other galaxies also apply to this lenticular (S0-type) system.  
**Why it matters:** pinning down the black-hole mass lets us test how galaxies and their central monsters co-evolve, and helps refine the cosmic “scaling laws” that astronomers use to estimate black-hole masses in galaxies too distant for direct measurement.

security proof of practical quantum key distribution ( qkd ) has attracted a lot of attentions in recent years . 
 most of real - life qkd implementations are based on phase - coding bb84 protocol , which usually uses unbalanced mach - zehnder interferometer ( umzi ) as the information coder and decoder . 
 however , the long arm and short arm of umzi will introduce different loss in practical experimental realizations , the state emitted by alice s side is nolonger standard bb84 states . in this paper

 counterintuitively , active compensation for this different loss will only lower the secret key bit rate .
output:
Imagine two people, Alice and Bob, trying to create a secret key by sending single particles of light.  
They use a “phase-coding BB84” recipe: each particle takes two possible paths inside a tiny maze of mirrors called an unbalanced Mach-Zehnder interferometer.  
In practice one path is longer and leaks more light, so the particles Bob receives are no longer the “perfect” BB84 states.  
We prove that the key can still be kept safe even with this mismatch.  
Surprisingly, trying to “fix” the extra loss with extra hardware only slows the key down.  
Knowing this lets engineers build simpler, cheaper quantum key systems without sacrificing security.

Imagine a tiny metal loop, smaller than a fingernail, threaded by a magnetic field. When electrons race through it, they leave a ghost current that keeps flowing—unless two barriers inside the ring trip them.  

Rafael found three ways this ghost survives:  
- a whisper-quiet off-resonance flow,  
- a bold current that ignores how thick the barriers are (true resonance),  
- a tricky one that behaves as if only one barrier exists (semi-resonance).  

Which flavor surge depends on how far apart the barriers sit on the loop and how much the electrons repel each other; stronger repulsion favors the semi-resonance path.  

**Consequences:**  
- True resonance stays steady, semi-resonance fades when temperature rises.

Think of a crowded car park: heavier vehicles (here, double stars) roll closer to the centre, while lighter cars (single, small stars) drift toward the edges.

Imagine a tiny checkerboard where each square is a quantum “spin” that can point in any direction.  
We used a super-precise computer trick (exact diagonalization) to listen to the board’s natural hum.  
When the spins secretly agree to all tilt the same way, two sounds appear:  
1) a heavy “Higgs” thump (the drumbeat of the new order)  
2) a soft “Goldstone” whisper (the gentle wave that costs no energy to slide sideways).  

We found that the heavy thump actually sits inside the sea of whispers, and nobody had checked what happens right at the melting point where the order is about to disappear.  
By making the checkerboard a little larger and tuning the squares to interact a little more, we sharpened the picture near the critical point and measured how the two sounds’ strengths relate.  
Why care?  It lets us hear how broken symmetry heals itself, a basic tune shared by magnets, superconductors, and maybe even the early universe.

Imagine a tiny generator that makes electricity from ordinary vibrations—like the buzz in your phone or the hum in a room. We built one from two small magnets glued to bendy plastic strips. When the strips wiggle, the magnets move through a magnetic field and create electricity. We added gentle, random shaking (think of a bus seat on a bumpy road) and measured how much electricity comes out. 

We found that if we make the magnets slightly different weights and let the distance between them change, the generator produces useful power across a wider range of shaking speeds, not just at one sweet spot. This matters because real-world vibrations are messy and spread over many frequencies. Our setup turns more of that messy motion into electricity, bringing us closer to self-charging sensors for bridges, shoes, or even coffee machines.

output: Imagine a toy stock market drawn on graph paper: every square holds a tiny trader who only knows yesterday’s prices.  We let the whole sheet stretch or shrink like a rubber sheet—this “dilation” trick keeps prices almost fair, allowing only pocket-money-sized mistakes.  After each round we gently nudge the layout; over time the sheet settles into a sand-pile shape where small avalanches (price jumps) feel just like the real world. Studying this stripped-down game helps us see why even perfect fairness can still produce wild swings, and suggests one reason real markets keep landing on the edge of trouble.

Imagine you have a photo of a sunset, but you only know the final image** – no camera settings, no location, no time of day.  
**Goal:** work backwards to guess the camera settings that could have produced the sunset.  

**The Twist:**  
- The only way to check a set of settings is to simulate a new image and see if it matches the photo.  
- If the settings are wrong, the simulation **fails completely** – no partial credit, no gradient, no clue how close you were.  
3. **The Challenge:** most algorithms waste time on settings that will never work.  
4. **The Solution:** **Bayesian optimization** – a smart sampler that:  
- **rejects** obviously wrong paths early (avoids expensive simulations),  
- **keeps a pool of candidates** that **worked so far**, and  
- **adaptively picks** the next settings to test, balancing **exploration** vs **exploitation**.  
5. **The Result:**  
- **10× fewer simulations** needed to find good camera settings.  
- **No need to open the camera** – just the sunset photo is enough.

Imagine YouTube keeps showing you the same viral cat video because millions already clicked.  
We built a simple “toy world” of viewers and videos to watch what happens over months.  
The loop works like this: the site suggests what’s already popular, people click it, so it becomes even more popular, so it gets suggested more—an endless circle.  

Our model shows this circle can squeeze variety: a few items shoot to stardom while the rest stay hidden, the way one loud voice drowns out a choir.  
Looking at real apps, we see the same winner-take-all pattern grow over time.  

Good news: by letting the algorithm be slightly less “accurate” today—occasionally slipping in less-clicked choices—we can keep the long-tail of videos alive and viewers still find stuff they like.  

Why it matters: if we understand the feedback loop, we can design recommender systems that stay helpful without turning the internet into a never-ending rerun.

Think of a network as a city map: some streets form tight-knit neighborhoods, while others are dead-end alleys.  
Classic “spectral” tools—math that reads the map like a GPS—get lost in sparse cities with lots of alleys.  
A newer GPS rule, the “non-backtracker,” refuses to U-turn; this avoids getting stuck on busy hubs but completely skips alleys, so it can miss whole neighborhoods.  

We added a twist: our “reluctant backtracker” usually refuses to U-turn yet occasionally allows it, so alleys are explored but hubs still don’t hijack the route.  
On sparse test cities and real ones (including friendship and brain data), the reluctant guide finds neighborhoods the strict no-U-turn guide misses, without losing accuracy elsewhere.  

The trick that matters most: whether the guide normalizes street probabilities so traffic is conserved at every intersection.  
This simple choice, not the U-turn rule itself, turns out to decide success, hinting that real networks hide structure beyond just neighborhoods.

Imagine you have a pile of sand shaped like a bell curve. If you slide two such piles together, the new pile keeps the same smooth, downward-curved shape. That “shape never gets worse” property is called log-concavity.

Knowing that the shape is preserved matters: it guarantees that computer algorithms used in statistics, machine-learning and even drug-discovery run faster and give answers we can trust.

By watching how these stars move, we picked out three cool, dim “L dwarfs” and one even cooler “T dwarf” traveling with the Ursa Major group, plus five L and two T dwarfs moving with the Hyades group. Imagine a crowd of tiny compass needles that would love to line up, but the floor underneath is rumpled so badly that some needles can’t decide which way to point.  That “rumpled floor” is called magnetic frustration.

We built a simple Lego-style model of the needles, tweaked only two knobs—pressure and a small magnetic field—and then pressed “play.”  Inside a real crystal the atoms behaved exactly the same way: the nuclear “heartbeat” (a measurable echo) slowed down just as our model predicted.  

Why care?  Because when we learn how to quiet, or amplify, this frustration we gain a new dial to steer magnetic devices without rewiring the whole material.

output: Imagine the early universe as a stretching rubber sheet that can expand differently in every direction. We modeled this sheet carrying two “tilted” cosmic fluids—think of them as two winds blowing at angles to the sheet. Each wind carries energy across the sheet, but their flows cancel so the sheet stays smooth. When we wind the clock backward, the sheet keeps the same uneven Kasner-like shape as long as both winds move slower than light. These simple rules help us see how the universe might have chosen its present shape.

We used the Herschel satellite to spot far-infrared light from carbon monoxide (CO) gas in the galaxy NGC 1068. We found 11 emission lines, all within the galaxy's central region.
