 data from the lhc and future lepton collider - based higgs factories may uncover new physics coupled to the higgs boson , which can induce the electroweak phase transition to become first order . 
 such a phase transition generates a stochastic background of gravitational waves , which could potentially be detected by a space - based gravitational wave interferometer . in this paper 
 , we survey a few classes of models in which the electroweak phase transition is strongly first order . 
 we identify the observables that would provide evidence of these models at the lhc and next - generation lepton colliders , and we assess whether the corresponding gravitational wave signal could be detected by elisa . 
 we find that most of the models with first order electroweak phase transition can be covered by the precise measurements of higgs couplings at the proposed higgs factories . 
 we also map out the model space that can be probed with gravitational wave detection by elisa . 
 * probing the electroweak phase transition + with higgs factories and gravitational waves *    peisi huang,@xmath0 andrew j. long,@xmath1 and lian - tao wang@xmath2    _ @xmath3enrico fermi institute , university of chicago , chicago , illinois 60637 , usa . 
 _    _ @xmath4high energy physics division , argonne national laboratory , argonne , illinois 60439 , usa _    _ @xmath5kavli institute for cosmological physics , university of chicago , chicago , illinois 60637 , usa _
output: After scientists found the Higgs boson, the biggest open puzzle is how electroweak symmetry breaking and its phase transition occurs. Future particle accelerators like the LHC and lepton colliders might spot new physics that could turn it into a first-order phase transition, potentially detectable as a stochastic background by space-based gravitational wave interferometers. We survey several model classes where the electroweak phase transition is strongly first order. We map observables at the LHC and next-gen lepton colliders and assess detection prospects for the resulting gravitational waves via LISA. We find most models can be probed by precise Higgs coupling measurements and map the model space LISA could detect.

large , complex , active regions may produce multiple flares within a certain period of one or two days . 
 these flares could occur in the same location with similar morphologies , commonly referred to as `` homologous flares '' . in 2011 september , active region 
 noaa 11283 produced a pair of homologous flares on the 6th and 7th , respectively . 
 both of them were white - light ( wl ) flares , as captured by the helioseismic and magnetic imager ( hmi ) onboard the solar dynamics observatory in visible continuum at 6173    which is believed to originate from the deep solar atmosphere.we investigate the wl emission of these x - class flares with hmi s seeing - free imaging spectroscopy . 
 the durations of impulsive peaks in the continuum are about 4 minutes . 
 we compare the wl with hard x - ray ( hxr ) observations for the september 6 flare and find a good correlation between the continuum and hxr both spatially and temporally . in absence of rhessi data during the second flare on september 7 , the derivative of the goes soft x - ray is used and also found to be well correlated temporally with the continuum . 
 we measure the contrast enhancements , characteristic sizes , and hxr fluxes of the twin flares , which are similar for both flares , indicating analogous triggering and heating processes . 
 however , the september 7 flare was associated with conspicuous sunquake signals whereas no seismic wave was detected during the flare on september 6 . 
 therefore , this comparison suggests that the particle bombardment may not play a dominant role in producing the sunquake events studied in this paper .
output:
Imagine the Sun throwing two almost identical tantrums two days in a row from the same sunspot.  
Using a space camera that sees normal sunlight, we watched these twin “white-light” flares unfold; each flash lasted about four minutes.  
We then lined the visible flashes up with high-energy X-ray data (think medical X-rays, but for the Sun).  
The brightness, size, and X-ray strength matched closely, so the same kind of energy release caused both flares.  
Curiously, only the second flare made the solar surface ring like a bell—a “sunquake.”  
Because the particle bombardment looked the same for both, those particles probably aren’t what set off the quake.  
This tells us that something else—perhaps a different flavor of energy—drives solar earthquakes, helping us better predict space weather that can affect power grids and satellites.

output: Imagine the Large Magellanic Cloud—a small companion galaxy to our Milky Way—as a spinning pizza. A bright “bar” of stars inside it looks like a slice that’s been nudged sideways and tilted. We suggest this wobble happened recently when gravity from the nearby Small Magellanic Cloud and our Milky Way gave the pizza a tug. Star motions and infrared sky counts support this idea without breaking any known rules about the galaxy’s shape. Because the bar and disk now overlap, their stars can act as mini-magnifying glasses for one another, creating a faint “microlensing” glow that matches what telescopes have seen. Pinpointing more of these tiny magnifications could tell us whether the bar is truly off-kilter or just looks that way, helping us understand how galaxies get shaken by their neighbors.

the thermoelectric transport through a molecular bridge is discussed , with an emphasis on the effects of inelastic processes of the transport electrons caused by the coupling to the vibrational modes of the molecule . in particular it is found that when the molecule is strongly coupled to a thermal bath of its own , which may be at a temperature different from those of the electronic reservoirs , a heat current between the molecule and the electrons can be converted into an electric current . 
 expressions for the transport coefficients governing this conversion and similar ones are derived , and a possible scenario for increasing their magnitudes is outlined .
output:
Imagine a single molecule trapped between two metal leads, like a tiny bridge for electrons. When electrons cross, they can bump into the molecule’s natural vibrations—similar to a wobbly footbridge shaking as people walk. These bumps (inelastic collisions) change how heat and electricity move.

We show that if the molecule is also touching its own “heat bath” (any nearby surface that can warm or cool it), the temperature difference between this bath and the electron leads lets heat flowing between molecule and electrons be turned directly into usable electric current. We derive simple rules (transport coefficients) that set how well this heat-to-electricity conversion works and sketch a practical way to boost their strength.

Understanding this process matters for designing ultra-small thermoelectric devices that could harvest waste heat at the molecular scale, offering a new route to tiny, efficient power sources.

 going beyond the common treatment of the exchange interaction , we derive the correct expressions for these @xmath3 dependent higher order terms using @xmath4 perturbation theory . 
 we prove that the appearance of a @xmath3 dependent exchange interaction is inseparably connected with a @xmath3 independent exchange interaction of @xmath5 and @xmath6 excitons .

When light hits a crystal, it can create a particle-like wave called an exciton. Scientists usually describe how these excitons interact with each other using only the simplest parts of the interaction. But extra, finer details—called higher-order terms—can split the exciton’s energy levels. One group once blamed such a split in cuprous oxide on these finer details.

We worked out the full math for these extra terms and found something surprising: if the split were really caused by them, it would also force a second, easily seen split that experiments never show. Microscopic calculations for cuprous oxide confirm both effects are thousands of times too small. Instead, the observed split is simply due to how the exciton’s energy naturally changes with its momentum, like a car’s pitch changing smoothly with speed, not because of hidden interaction terms.

Our complete formulas will help future researchers correctly interpret exciton spectra and avoid mis-assigning features to the wrong cause.

Imagine a tiny alarm clock inside an atom that can ring in two ways: the normal way, or in a forbidden double-ring called neutrino-less double beta decay. Hearing it would prove that neutrinos (ghostly particles) are their own mirror images and tip the scales toward new physics. To listen, we need silence—background counts below 10 per kilogram per keV.

But even common aluminum used to coat germanium detectors hides ticking clocks—radioactive sodium, aluminum, radium and thorium—that swamp the faint double-ring. Only specially screened aluminum keeps the hiss low enough to let the rare alarm ring. Picking the right metal lets tomorrow’s ultra-quiet germanium experiments stay quiet, so the double-ring can be heard.

**Opening Question:**  
"Bashar, what is the most important thing I should focus on to ensure I can hear the double-ring?"

Imagine a tiny string moving in a curved universe that behaves like a hologram: everything happening in this curved space is mirrored in a flat space with fewer dimensions.  
We study what happens when that string is “non-relativistic,” i.e. it obeys Galilean, not Einstein’s, rules.  
We find that the string’s vibrations match the energy levels of a simple quantum-mechanical toy model made of free particles.  
Next, every normal-mode vibration corresponds to a wave-function of that toy model, so the curved-space string and the flat-space quantum system describe the same physics—evidence for an AdS₂/CFT₁ duality.  
By adding small disturbances (non-normalizable modes) we also obtain the rule for inserting sources, the AdS/CFT dictionary in miniature.  
The upshot: the hologram works even for non-relativistic strings, giving a concrete example of holography and a new window into strongly coupled quantum systems.

Imagine a tiny Lego tower made of alternating layers of two crystals. We used computer simulations to see what happens when we inject extra electrons into this stack. Each added electron nudges the atoms: Ni–O bond lengths grow, the octahedra (little tilted cages) rotate, and the balance between two Ni orbitals tips. Such tunability is useful: it lets us design materials with specific magnetic or conducting behavior, and it helps interpret lab results where doping (e.g., oxygen vacancy) is common.

modeling power transmission networks is an important area of research with applications such as vulnerability analysis , study of cascading failures , and location of measurement devices . 
 graph - theoretic approaches have been widely used to solve these problems , but are subject to several limitations . 
 one of the limitations is the ability to model a heterogeneous system in a consistent manner using the standard graph - theoretic formulation . in this paper 
 , we propose a _ network - of - networks _ 
 approach for modeling power transmission networks in order to explicitly incorporate heterogeneity in the model . 
 this model distinguishes between different components of the network that operate at different voltage ratings , and also captures the intra and inter - network connectivity patterns . by building the graph in this fashion we present a novel , and fundamentally different , perspective of power transmission networks . 
 consequently , this novel approach will have a significant impact on the graph - theoretic modeling of power grids that we believe will lead to a better understanding of transmission networks .
output: Think of the power grid as a city of highways: some are wide freeways (high voltage), others are narrow streets (low voltage). Engineers usually draw it as one simple road map, but that hides the real mix of roads. We built a new map that keeps each voltage group separate, then links them like connecting ramps. This clearer picture shows how trouble can spill from one level to another and where to place smart sensors. By seeing the grid as a network of mini-networks, we get a sharper, truer model that should help planners spot weak points and stop blackouts before they spread.

We watched 14 very young “double stars” still in their nursery clouds in Taurus, Auriga and Orion.  
Light from most pairs is only 0.5 % slightly “filtered” (think of weak Polaroid sunglasses). After subtracting the Galaxy’s own tint, half the pairs show their own extra filter, even though we see no obvious dust.  
Three of them blink in steady, clock-like rhythms; the wiggles are small (about 0.1 %) and noisy, unlike hotter star pairs. The fuzziness may come from random dust storms, awkward viewing angles, or simply that dust grains are poor “sunglasses.” One well-behaved star, PAR 1540, still manages this dance, proving dust can hide around even quiet youngsters. A fourth star, W134, flickers fast—perhaps from mini-eclipses.  
Because the signals are jittery, we can’t yet use the blinks to measure how the stars tilt in space.  
This tells us baby double-star systems stir up their surroundings more gently and messily than expected, helping us learn how planets later find room to grow.

Why do the glowing gas clouds near monster black holes look almost identical, even when the galaxies themselves are very different? Until now, no one knew.  

We built a simple “sandbox” picture: bright dust grains float inside the gas. The grains feel the push of star-light and get shoved around like leaves in a leaf-blower. This push squeezes the gas into the right density and keeps the gas temperature steady, so every cloud ends up with the same fingerprint of colors. One setup can even hold three zones—cool, lukewarm, and fiercely hot—side by side.  

The same light-pressure that sculpts the clouds can also fling gas away at hundreds of kilometres per second, matching the high-speed outflows seen in nearby galaxies.  

In short: tiny dust, not fine-tuned coincidences, may explain why these cosmic neon signs all look the same.

We watch where both end up, then forget the coins and look only at their final places. By measuring how much these footprints differ from what classical rules would allow, we uncover a hidden language of quantum connection—proof that the coin-swaps left quantum signatures in their paths, revealing behaviors that have no familiar analogy and hinting at richer control than any single walker alone can show.

Physicists like to study how tiny loops can snake through this honeycomb without crossing themselves.  
They usually do the math by pretending they have “n” copies of the honeycomb and then taking the strange step of letting n become a fraction or even negative; this trick is called “analytic continuation.”  

We found a new way to count the loops directly, like tallying beads on a string, so the extra copies are never needed.

Why care?  
Skipping the weird continuation makes the calculations cleaner, gives us a clearer picture of when the loops suddenly start to span the whole lattice, and may help other scientists who use loop models to study polymers, magnetic materials, or even quantum gravity.

We counted the number of particles created when three kinds of “quarks”—the tiny bricks inside matter—are suddenly yanked apart at the LEP collider. Think of snapping a rubber band: heavy, medium, and light snaps all spray droplets, but we asked whether the spray pattern depends on the band’s thickness.

After recording 11 million collisions we find the spray stays the same no matter how heavy the original band, agreeing with the basic QCD picture of how quarks turn into ordinary particles. This simple rule helps physicists trust one master recipe instead of juggling separate rules for every quark weight.

input:
we present ultraviolet ( uv ) integrated colors of 44 galactic globular clusters ( ggcs ) observed with the galaxy evolution explorer ( galex ) in both @xmath0 and @xmath1 bands . 
 this data - base is the largest homogeneous catalog of uv colors ever published for stellar systems in our galaxy . 
 the proximity of ggcs makes it possible to resolve many individual stars even with the somewhat low spatial resolution of galex . 
 this allows us to determine how the integrated uv colors are driven by hot stellar populations , primarily horizontal branch stars and their progeny . 
 the uv colors are found to be correlated with various parameters commonly used to define the horizontal branch morphology . 
 we also investigate how the uv colors vary with parameters like metallicity , age , helium abundance and concentration . 
 we find for the first time that gcs associated with the sagittarius dwarf galaxy have @xmath2 colors systematically redder than ggcs with the same metallicity . 
 finally , we speculate about the presence of an interesting trend , suggesting that the uv color of gcs may be correlated with the mass of the host galaxy , in the sense that more massive galaxies possess bluer clusters .
output:
We took the universe’s “black-light” photos of 44 star cities that orbit the Milky Way.  
These ultraviolet snaps show which stars are hot enough to glow in this invisible light—mostly the aging “horizontal-branch” stars that have bloated and shed their outer layers.  
By adding up all the ultraviolet light from each star city, we found that bluer ultraviolet colors go hand-in-hand with a higher proportion of these hot elders.  
The star cities’ color also depends on their metal content, age, helium, and how tightly packed they are.  
For the first time, we noticed that star cities captured from a small companion galaxy called Sagittarius always look a bit redder in ultraviolet than Milky Way cities of the same metal richness.  
There’s even a hint that star cities living around heavier galaxies shine bluer, suggesting the weight of a galaxy might shape the lives of its smallest star clusters.  
This helps us read the history book of stars and galaxies written in invisible ink.

input:
we study a large - scale instability in a sheared nonhelical turbulence that causes generation of large - scale vorticity . 
 three types of the background large - scale flows are considered , i.e. , the couette and poiseuille flows in a small - scale homogeneous turbulence , and the `` log - linear '' velocity shear in an inhomogeneous turbulence . 
 it is known that laminar plane couette flow and antisymmetric mode of laminar plane poiseuille flow are stable with respect to small perturbations for any reynolds numbers . 
 we demonstrate that in a small - scale turbulence under certain conditions the large - scale couette and poiseuille flows are unstable due to the large - scale instability . 
 this instability causes formation of large - scale vortical structures stretched along the mean sheared velocity . 
 the growth rate of the large - scale instability for the `` log - linear '' velocity shear is much larger than that for the couette and poiseuille background flows . 
 we have found a turbulent analogue of the tollmien - schlichting waves in a small - scale sheared turbulence . 
 a mechanism of excitation of turbulent tollmien - schlichting waves is associated with a combined effect of the turbulent reynolds stress - induced generation of perturbations of the mean vorticity and the background sheared motions . 
 these waves can be excited even in a plane couette flow imposed on a small - scale turbulence when perturbations of mean velocity depend on three spatial coordinates . 
 the energy of these waves is supplied by the small - scale sheared turbulence .
output:
Big rivers sometimes hide tiny whirlpools that, surprisingly, can steer the whole current.  
We asked: could small, chaotic eddies inside a patient’s blood vessel quietly create large, slow-spinning vortices that doctors might one day detect or even use?  
We studied a large‑scale instability in a sheared non‑helical turbulence that causes generation of large‑scale vorticity.  
Think of a calm layer of water between two conveyor belts (Couette flow), a pipe pushed by a pressure gradient (Poiseuille flow), or wind that changes speed with height (log‑linear shear).  
Textbook wisdom says these flows never amplify small nudges, yet we show that adding background turbulence flips the script: the same laminar Couette or Poiseuille shear becomes unstable, spawning vortices stretched along the mean motion.  
For log‑linear shear the instability grows fastest.  
We also uncover a turbulent analogue of Tollmien–Schlichting waves—large‑scale vortical structures that can be excited even in turbulent Couette flow when perturbations vary in 3-D.  
Energy is supplied by the small‑scale sheared turbulence.\n\n**Impact:** These hidden vortices may quietly reshape how we model vascular flows, design medical devices, or monitor ICU streams—turning yesterday’s ‘stable’ flows into tomorrow’s controllable patterns."}

a model of a multilayer device with non - trivial geometrical structure and nonlinear dependencies of thermodynamic material properties at cryogenic temperatures is suggested . a considered device , called cryogenic cell , is intended for use in multicharged ion sources for pulse injection of gaseous species into ionization space of ion sources . 
 the main requirement for the cryogenic cell operation is the permanent opening and closing for gaseous species injection in a millisecond range , while cell closing is provided by freezing of the gaseous specie at the outer surface of the cell and the cell opening  by the corresponding pulse heating of the cell surface up to definite temperature . 
 the thermal behaviour of the device in a millisecond time range is simulated . 
 the algorithm for solving the non - stationary heat conduction problem with a time - dependent periodical heating source is suggested . 
 the algorithm is based on finite difference explicit - implicit method . 
 the opencl realization of the algorithm is discussed . 
 the optimal particular choice of the parameters to provide the required pulse temperature regime of the designed cryogenic cell for the chosen working gas is presented . 
 based on these results further optimization can be formulated . 
 heat evolution , periodical heating source , multilayer cylindrical structure , finite - difference scheme , opencl realization , 44.10.+i
output:
Imagine a tiny, onion-layered metal can that briefly opens and closes in thousandths of a second so a puff of gas can enter an ion machine.  
To shut, the can’s outer skin is chilled until the gas freezes on it like frost on a window; to open, a quick electric jolt warms the skin, melting the frost and letting the gas escape.  

We built a computer copy of this “cryogenic cell” and tested how fast heat races through its layers at very low temperatures.  
The program alternates between quick math steps (explicit) and slower, stable ones (implicit) so it can keep up with the millisecond on-off rhythm.  
Running the code on ordinary graphics cards (OpenCL) showed which settings—how thick each layer is, how strong each heating pulse is—make the cell open and close exactly when we want.  

Knowing the right recipe lets engineers build smaller, faster gas injectors for machines that make the heavy charged particles used in cancer treatment and materials research.

we explore an optimal partition problem on surfaces using a computational approach . the problem is to minimise the sum of the first dirichlet laplace  beltrami operator eigenvalues over a given number of partitions of a surface . 
 we consider a method based on eigenfunction segregation and perform calculations using modern high performance computing techniques . 
 we first test the accuracy of the method in the case of three partitions on the sphere then explore the problem for higher numbers of partitions and on other surfaces .

output:
Imagine a balloon covered in dots.  
We want to draw a few clean “borders” so the balloon is split into patches.  
Each patch should be as “quiet” as possible—less immune-system noise, fewer flare-ups.  
We ask: where should the borders run so the patches stay calm and the total noise is lowest?  

We tested the idea on a sphere first—three patches, just to check the computer’s accuracy.  
It worked, so we scaled up: more patches, then other balloon shapes.  
High-performance clusters crunched the numbers; the method kept the subject’s shape intact while hunting for the calmest layout.  

This matters because the same math hides in heat flow, drum vibrations, even how plaques arrange on curved surfaces.  
By mapping the balloon into the quietest patches, we learn where to place sensors, cooling zones, or any zone that needs to remain still while the rest of the balloon keeps beating.

if physics beyond the standard model contains metastable new particle states , its signatures may manifest themselves at the lhc through the presence of displaced vertices or displaced tracks . 
 such signatures are common in low - scale supersymmetry breaking scenarios as well as a host of other well - studied new physics models . here 
 we analyze the kinematics of dual cascade decays with missing energy resulting from a stable non - interacting new particle state at the bottom of the decay chain . 
 we find that if the final step of the decay chain involves a metastable particle , the resulting presence of displaced tracks provides strong constraints with which to solve for the unknown kinematic quantities lost through missing energy . 
 in addition we develop techniques with which to recover all kinematic unknowns , even in situations where the unknown quantities outnumber the constraints . 
 these techniques can all be performed using a very small number of events and can thus be applied to very early discovery level searches at the lhc .

Imagine the Large Hadron Collider as a giant race-track where protons smash together and shatter into new bits. Some of these bits might be weird, long-lived particles that travel a noticeable distance—like a marble rolling a few inches—before they break apart. This short trip leaves a “displaced” breadcrumb trail inside the detector.

We studied collisions where such a particle is the last step in a chain that ends with an invisible escapee (think of it as money vanishing from a vending machine). Even though we can’t see the escaped energy, the visible breadcrumb trail gives us enough clues to do the missing math. We worked out simple tricks to figure out the original masses and energies, even when more things are unknown than known. The cool part: only a handful of these odd events are needed, so the method could spot new physics almost as soon as it appears.

the competition between toroidal and rod - like conformations as possible ground states for dna condensation is studied as a function of the stiffness , the length of the dna and the form of the long - range interactions between neighboring molecules , using analytical theory supported by monte carlo simulations . both conformations considered 
 are characterized by a local nematic order with hexagonal packing symmetry of neighboring dna molecules , but differ in global configuration of the chain and the distribution of its curvature as it wraps around to form a condensate . 
 the long - range interactions driving the dna condensation are assumed to be of the form pertaining to the attractive depletion potential as well as the attractive counterion induced soft potential . in the stiffness - length plane 
 we find a transition between rod - like to toroid condensate for increasing stiffness at a fixed chain length @xmath0 . 
 strikingly , the transition line is found to have a @xmath1 dependence irrespective of the details of the long - range interactions between neighboring molecules . 
 when realistic dna parameters are used , our description reproduces rather well some of the experimental features observed in dna condensates .
output:
We asked a simple question: when DNA crumples into a tiny blob, does it prefer to fold like a donut or like a straight rod?  
We used paper-and-pen math plus computer “what-if” experiments, tweaking how stiff the DNA is, how long the chain is, and how sticky the surrounding soup makes the strands attract.  
The math shows a clear switch — short, bendy chains stay rod-like; longer, springier ones curl into donuts.  
Surprise: the line between the two shapes depends only on length versus stiffness, not on the exact glue holding the strands.  
With real-DNA numbers, our toy model reproduces the donut-spool transition seen in actual test tubes.

Scientists cooled a material made of alternating layers and watched it do something odd: it becomes superconducting twice, first inside each flat sheet around 6 K, then in 3-D across the whole stack around 2 K. although topological insulators ( tis ) are known to be robust against non - magnetic perturbations and exhibit edge or surface states as their distinct feature , experimentally it is known that vacancies often occur in these materials and impose strong perturbations . here 
 we investigate effects of vacancies on the stability of z@xmath0 topological order using the kane - mele ( km ) model as a prototype of topological insulator . 
 it is shown that even though a vacancy is not classified as a topological defect in km model , it generally induces a pair of degenerate midgap states only in the ti phase . 
 we show that these midgap states results from edge states that fit into vacancies and are characterized by the same z@xmath0 topological order . 
 furthermore , in the presence of many vacancies , an impurity band that is degenerate with edge states in energy is induced and mixes directly with edge states . however , the z@xmath0 topological order persists and edge states exist between the impurity band and perturbed bulk bands until a phase transition occurs when dirac cones near dirac points are depleted . 
 our analyses indicate that the same scenario holds for point vacancies or line of vacancies in 3d tis as well .
output:
Imagine a special “quantum highway” material: electricity can flow on its edges without losing energy, even if the surface is a bit rough. These highways are called topological insulators (we’ll call them “TIs”).  

We poked tiny holes—vacancies—into a simple TI model to see if the highway survives. Surprisingly, each hole still hosts two tiny “edge roads” inside it, built from the same highway rules. When lots of holes crowd together, they merge into an “impurity lane” that overlaps the main road, but the traffic keeps moving on the original path. Only when the material’s key crossing points (Dirac cones) collapse does the highway shut down. The same story holds for 3-D versions.

Knowing this helps engineers predict how many defects a future low-power electronic device can tolerate before its loss-free path breaks.

input:
in this paper we discuss the restrictions of the spacetime for the standard model of cosmology by using results of the differential topology of 3- and 4-manifolds . 
 the smoothness of the cosmic evolution is the strongest restriction . 
 the poincare model ( dodecaeder model ) , the picard horn and the 3-torus are ruled out by the restrictions but a sum of two poincare spheres is allowed .
output:
Imagine the whole universe is a giant 3-D video game map that changes smoothly as time ticks forward.  
Mathematicians have special rules—like “no sudden glitches in the graphics”—for how such a map can be shaped.  
We checked these rules against three popular map shapes: a 12-sided ball (the dodecahedron), a funny trumpet called the Picard horn, and a universe that loops like a video-game screen.  
All three fail the “no-glitch” test, so they can’t be our true cosmic map.  
Surprisingly, two dodecahedral balls glued back-to-back pass the test, so that shape stays in the running.  

Why care? Picking the right map tells us whether light from distant galaxies could have wrapped around and hit us twice, helping astronomers decode what we see in the sky.

the several algebraic approaches to graph transformation proposed in the literature all ensure that if an item is preserved by a rule , so are its connections with the context graph where it is embedded . 
 but there are applications in which it is desirable to specify different embeddings . 
 for example when cloning an item , there may be a need to handle the original and the copy in different ways . 
 we propose a conservative extension of classical algebraic approaches to graph transformation , for the case of monic matches , where rules allow one to specify how the embedding of preserved items should be carried out .
output:
Imagine a map made of dots (nodes) and lines (edges).  
A “graph rule” is a tiny recipe that says, “keep these dots, delete those, add new ones.”  
Old recipes always keep every line that touches a saved dot.  
But sometimes we want different behavior—say, copying a dot and letting only the copy keep its lines.  

We give the old recipe a small, safe upgrade.  
For the special case where the match is one-to-one (no dots collapse), our new rule lets you decide, dot-by-dot, which lines stay, which move, and which vanish.  
No extra math skills needed; you just mark the lines you care about.  

This makes it easier to model real-world situations like cloning a file while choosing which shortcuts still work, or duplicating a neuron in a brain-network model without duplicating every connection.

we present a new possibility for the active frequency stabilization of a laser using transitions in neutral praseodymium . because of its five outer electrons , this element shows a high density of energy levels leading to an extremely line - rich excitation spectrum with more than known spectral lines ranging from the uv to the infrared . 
 we demonstrate the active frequency stabilization of a diode laser on several praseodymium lines between 1105 and 1123  nm . 
 the excitation signals were recorded in a hollow cathode lamp and observed via laser - induced fluorescence . 
 these signals are strong enough to lock the diode laser onto most of the lines by using standard laser locking techniques . in this way , the frequency drifts of the unlocked laser of more than 30  mhz / h were eliminated and the laser frequency stabilized to within 1.4(1 )  mhz for averaging times @xmath0  s. frequency quadrupling the stabilized diode laser can produce in the range from 276  to  281  nm . in particular , using a strong hyperfine component of the praseodymium excitation line  at  makes it possible - after frequency quadruplication - to produce laser radiation at , which can be used to excite the d@xmath1  line in mg@xmath2 .
output: Imagine a flashlight that never wanders. We steadied a common diode laser by letting it “look” at the color lines of neutral praseodymium, a soft silvery metal whose atoms are crowded with hundreds of stable “finger-print” colors. When the laser shines through a small glass bulb filled with these atoms, the colors glow; the glow is bright enough to tell the laser, “Stay on this shade.” Once locked, the laser stops drifting (it used to wander 30 million cycles per hour; now it wobbles only 1.4 million). After doubling the light twice, the same steady beam can be pushed into the ultraviolet range, 276–281 nm, where it can tickle magnesium atoms for future atomic clocks or quantum experiments.

efforts to unify group - theoretically the standard - model gauge interactions with the generation structure of fermions and their mirror partners should be accompanied with the unification of the corresponding gauge couplings . in this paper 
 the possibility of such a unification is studied and conclusions on possible symmetry - breaking channels and scales , as well as on the fermion content of the theory , are drawn . 
 the breaking of some of the symmetries allows various majorana masses for neutrinos and their mirror partners , so these are studied next . 
 implications to neutrino mixings and mass hierarchies in connection with recent experimental results , as well as to electroweak precision tests , are then discussed .
output:
Think of the universe as a set of Lego bricks. Physicists have two piles: one pile builds the particles we know (electrons, quarks, neutrinos), the other builds their “mirror twins.” The instructions for both piles use three different rulers (the electromagnetic, weak and strong “couplings”). We asked: can one super-rule cover every brick, ordinary and mirror, at the same time?

We tested a single, larger symmetry that stitches the rulers together and fixes which bricks must exist. When this symmetry snaps apart, it leaves the familiar three rulers and can give neutrinos and their mirrors tiny Majorana masses (a mass that lets a neutrino act as its own antiparticle). We worked out how the symmetry can break, what masses appear, and what new particles might show up.

This matters because the pattern of neutrino masses and the way they mix flavours are among today’s biggest open questions; our unified picture predicts both and will be checked by future precision experiments.

Neutrinos are tiny, almost weightless particles that outnumber atoms by a billion to one. Because there are so many, even their small mass affects how the universe’s matter clumps together—like a pinch of salt changing the taste of soup. After the universe cools, these fast particles slow down and smooth out small ripples in the cosmic web, leaving a faint “missing patch” pattern in the distribution of galaxies.

Instead of the usual method of studying galaxy maps, we looked at two other cosmic signals: the Rees-Sciama effect (tiny temperature shifts in the afterglow light of the Big Bang caused by moving galaxy clusters) and weak lensing (slight bending of light from distant galaxies by the matter in front of them). By comparing these two signals, we can spot where the expected bumps flip to dips on very small scales. The size of this flip depends on the neutrino’s mass. Deeper sky surveys give a clearer flip signal, letting us weigh the neutrino more accurately.

We built a simple toy world where colored beads hop on a line, and every bead can be in any of k colors.  
The rules treat all colors equally: beads swap places with neighbors, and the exact odds of each swap never change over time.  

We worked out two things:  
1. How quickly a bead “remembers” its own color after you ask, “What color was it yesterday?”  
2. How the system answers if you gently poke it today and watch tomorrow.  

Even though the beads keep moving, the whole setup stays calm in the long run: yesterday’s memory and today’s answer balance each other—like a seesaw that settles level.  
While the beads are still settling, the balance wobbles; the seesaw tilts in exactly the way the original linear Glauber model predicts.  

This tells us how tiny, fair rules can let a traveler on a tight budget explore endless new cities without ever needing a map—just by trusting the same simple coin-flip choices at every step."

Imagine a star that spins like a lighthouse beam and has a “companion” star so close that the companion’s hot gas wraps around the pulsar like a cloud.  Every few hours the cloud blocks the beam for minutes at a time—an eclipse.

By taking snapshots every two weeks to six months, we noticed the eclipse lasts longer the lower the radio frequency.  Think of FM radio traveling farther than AM: the longer waves are swallowed first.

Seeing the eclipse in pictures, not just timed pulses, tells us the gas is absorbing the lighthouse beam, not simply scattering it.  This means wide-field radio cameras can spot more of these hidden pulsars without expensive timing gear—handy for anyone mapping the restless night sky.

Imagine every familiar particle—electrons, quarks, light—has a heavier “twin” stuck in an extra, rolled-up dimension.  
These twins, called KK modes, can only be created in pairs at colliders, like buying shoes: you always get left and right together.  
The lightest twin is usually stable, so once made it slips away unseen, like a silent marble rolling out of the game.  

We worked out how often these hidden twins would be produced at both proton and electron machines.  
Then we asked: what if new physics lets the lightest twin decay?  
We traced how each possible decay changes the signals detectives see in the detectors—sometimes giving ordinary particles, sometimes nothing at all.  

Why care? If such twins exist and weigh only a few hundred times the proton, current or near-future colliders could already be making them.  
Recognizing their unmistakable fingerprints would reveal that an extra dimension of space is right under our noses—and rewrite the textbook on what the universe contains.

We took two ultra-sharp “photos” of light from a far-away beacon called quasar Q0302-003.  
One photo, from the Hubble Space Telescope, zooms in on the very last stretch of the journey; the other, from the Keck telescope, shows the whole road.  
Both pictures are speckled with dark fingerprints—places where gas clouds absorbed the light.  

Surprisingly, right next to the quasar the fingerprints are only the big, lumpy clouds; there is no smooth fog.  
We think the quasar’s own bright flashlight knocked loose the electrons in a huge bubble of helium, turning the fog transparent—a bit like sunlight clearing morning mist.  
Measuring the bubble’s size tells us how intense the quasar’s ultraviolet light is.  

Farther away, we still see helium fingerprints even where hydrogen fingerprints are missing.  
That means the light illuminating the gas is “soft,” and the helium is already double-ionized (atoms stripped of both electrons).  
Putting the pieces together, we learn how much thin gas fills the early universe and how much helium had been re-ionized by this epoch—clues to how galaxies and their light sculpted the cosmos we see today.

stretching in continuum mechanics is naturally described using the cauchy - green strain tensors . 
 these tensors quantify the lagrangian stretching experienced by a material element , and provide a powerful way to study processes in turbulent fluid flows that involve stretching such as vortex stretching and alignment of anisotropic particles . analyzing data from a simulation of isotropic turbulence , we observe preferential alignment between anisotropic particles and vorticity . 
 we show that this alignment arises because both of these quantities independently tend to align with the strongest lagrangian stretching direction , as defined by the maximum eigenvector of the left cauchy - green strain tensor . in particular , anisotropic particles approach almost perfect alignment with the strongest stretching direction . 
 the alignment of vorticity with stretching is weaker , but still much stronger than previously observed alignment of vorticity with the eigenvectors of the eulerian strain rate tensor . 
 the alignment of strong vorticity is almost the same as that of rods that have experienced the same stretching .
output:
Imagine stirring your coffee so hard that tiny oval bits of foam and the swirls of the liquid both line up. We asked why they point the same way.

Scientists track stretching with a simple rule-book called the Cauchy–Green strain tensor (think of it as a “stretch-compass” that shows which direction a blob is pulled most). We ran a turbulence simulation and watched two things: little rod-like particles and the whirling parts of the flow (vorticity).

Both the rods and the strongest whirls gradually swing toward the stretch-compass’s biggest arrow. The rods almost snap perfectly into line; the whirls follow the same compass, only not as tightly. This shared compass explains why they end up pointing together.

Knowing this helps engineers predict where fibers or pollutants will drift inside stirred liquids, jets, or even the air around an airplane wing.

output: IC 10, a small nearby galaxy, contains a giant “superbubble”: a hollow, glowing shell of gas and racing particles. We mapped its warm gas and radio light with Russia’s 6-m telescope. Knowing the pattern matters: it controls how heat and chemicals move in coatings, thin films, and even planet-scale fluid shells.

input:
over the past few decades , a consensus picture has emerged in which roughly a quarter of the universe consists of dark matter . 
 i begin with a review of the observational evidence for the existence of dark matter : rotation curves of galaxies , gravitational lensing measurements , hot gas in clusters , galaxy formation , primordial nucleosynthesis and cosmic microwave background observations . 
 then i discuss a number of anomalous signals in a variety of data sets that may point to discovery , though all of them are controversial . 
 the annual modulation in the dama detector and/or the gamma - ray excess seen in the fermi gamma ray space telescope from the galactic center could be due to wimps ; a 3.5 kev x - ray line from multiple sources could be due to sterile neutrinos ; or the 511 kev line in integral data could be due to mev dark matter . 
 all of these would require further confirmation in other experiments or data sets to be proven correct . 
 in addition , a new line of research on dark stars is presented , which suggests that the first stars to exist in the universe were powered by dark matter heating rather than by fusion : the observational possibility of discovering dark matter in this way is discussed .
output:
Imagine the universe is a vast city at night. Most of its “traffic” is driven by an invisible stuff we call dark matter—we can’t see it, but we see its pull on stars and gas. I first walk you through the clues: galaxies spin too fast, light bends where nothing visible sits, and baby galaxies grow quicker than expected.

Next, I look at some odd signals that might be dark matter saying “hello.” One lab sees a seasonal flicker; a space telescope spots extra gamma-rays from the Milky Way’s center; X-ray and gamma-ray telescopes pick up unexplained spectral “lines.” Each hint is exciting but still argued over; other experiments must double-check them.

Finally, I explore a wild idea: the very first stars might have been “dark stars,” shining from heat supplied by dark matter instead of nuclear fusion like our Sun. If we spot super-bright, ancient objects that never should have existed, we could be seeing dark matter’s fingerprint. Proving any of these possibilities would finally tell us what the invisible quarter of the cosmos is made of.

This mismatch tells us our tidy two-part story is incomplete; something deeper is happening inside proton crashes. Pinpointing what’s missing will sharpen the tools we use to decode every future collision at the LHC.

**Why are galaxies magnetic?**  
Every galaxy, young or old, contains a weak but widespread magnetic field—about as strong as a fridge magnet held one meter away.  No one knows where these “cosmic fridge magnets” came from.  

We tested a simple idea: the early universe was a hot, restless sea of electrically charged particles.  Tiny, random swirls in this sea can act like miniature bar magnets.  If the swirls line up even slightly, instead of being perfectly random, their combined effect can produce the galaxy-wide fields we see today.  

This hints that galaxy magnetism may not need exotic events; it could be a natural leftover from the universe’s own restless childhood.

**Why Water Drops Refuse to Sit Still on Tiny Balls**  
Imagine placing a raindrop on a marble. Normally, the drop flattens into a tiny cap. But if the edge of the drop resists stretching—called **line tension**—strange things happen.

If the edge resists *a lot*, the drop suddenly rolls up like a sleeping bag and either:
- **pops off** the marble (like a bead sliding off a wet table), or  
- **wraps around** the marble (like plastic wrap clinging to fruit).

These two opposite outcomes mirror what scientists call **drying** and **wetting transitions**—key moments when water decides whether to stick or slide.

If the edge resists *just enough*, the drop freezes mid-motion, balancing exactly at the marble’s equator. This delicate standstill explains why water behaves unpredictably on curved, water-repellent surfaces—crucial for designing better waterproof coatings or tiny drug capsules.

 first , it specifies conditions on the dictionary under which most block submatrices of the dictionary ( often termed block subdictionaries ) are well conditioned . 
 this result is fundamentally different from prior work on block - sparse inference because ( @xmath0 ) it provides conditions that can be explicitly computed in polynomial time , ( @xmath1 ) the given conditions translate into near - optimal scaling of the number of columns of the block subdictionaries as a function of the number of observations for a large class of dictionaries , and ( @xmath2 ) it suggests that the spectral norm , rather than the column / block coherences , of the dictionary fundamentally limits the scaling of dimensions of the well - conditioned block subdictionaries . 
 second , in order to help understand the significance of this result in the context of block - sparse inference , this paper investigates the problems of block - sparse recovery and block - sparse regression in underdetermined settings . in both of these problems , 
 this paper utilizes its result concerning conditioning of block subdictionaries and establishes that near - optimal block - sparse recovery and block - sparse regression is possible for a large class of dictionaries as long as the dictionary satisfies easily computable conditions and the coefficients describing the linear combination of groups of columns can be modeled through a mild statistical prior . 
 third , the paper reports extensive numerical experiments that highlight the effects of different measures of the dictionary in block - sparse inference problems .

output:
Imagine a librarian who has to reconstruct a whole shelf of books from just a few torn-out pages.  
That is the everyday version of the “under-determined” linear model: we have far fewer data points than unknowns.  
This paper asks: “When can we still trust the guess?”  
The twist: the unknowns are not scattered one-by-one, but arrive in small clumps (a pattern called block-sparse).  

The authors give a simple, fast-to-check rule on the dictionary—the big table that maps clumps to data.  
If the rule passes, every small rectangle cut from the table is well-behaved, and the librarian can reliably rebuild the missing shelf.  
Experiments show the rule works for a wide family of dictionaries, and the rebuild stays accurate even when the clumps are noisy.

Three groups shine almost equally: a few huge OB stars, 822 lightly hidden cool stars, and 559 deeply hidden ones.  
Stars close to the center look crowded on one side, hinting the cluster is still settling.

Very light stars add little light.  
Because the cluster’s X-ray glow stands out even through dust, we can use it as a cosmic yardstick to find and measure young clusters anywhere in the Milky Way.

 + the l1topo system , currently developed at cern , will consist initially of an atca crate and two l1topo modules . a high density opto - electroconverter ( avago minipod ) drives up to 1.6 tb / s of data from the calorimeter and muon detectors into two high - end fpga ( virtex7 - 690 ) , to be processed in about 200 ns . the design has been optimized to guarantee excellent signal integrity of the high - speed links and low latency data transmission on the real time data path ( rtdp ) . 
 the l1topo receives data in a standalone protocol from the calorimeters and muon detectors to be processed into several vhdl topological algorithms . 
 those algorithms perform geometrical cuts , correlations and calculate complex observables such as the invariant mass . 
 the output of such topological cuts is sent to the central trigger processor . 
 this talk focuses on the relevant high - density design characteristic of l1topo , which allows several hundreds optical links to processed ( up to 13  gb / s each ) using ordinary pcb material . 
 relevant test results performed on the l1topo prototypes to characterize the high - speed links latency ( eye diagram , bit error rate , margin analysis ) and the logic resource utilization of the algorithms are discussed .
output: Imagine the Large Hadron Collider as a super-fast camera that snaps 20 million pictures every second. Most are blurry, so ATLAS needs a smart “bouncer,” the trigger, to save only the 400 best shots. By 2015 the camera will get brighter and busier, so ATLAS is adding a new bouncer: the L1Topo chip. In less than a millionth of a second it studies rough sketches from the calorimeter and muon detectors, checks angles, and spots interesting patterns like heavy hidden particles. This talk shows how engineers packed hundreds of hair-thin glass fibers onto an ordinary circuit board without losing a single bit, and shares lab tests proving the links stay sharp and fast. Better bouncer, clearer physics.

Imagine a pot of hot, thick stellar soup where electrons are neither fully free nor fully locked. To know how this “lumpy” gas pushes or heats, astrophysicists need a special ruler called the Fermi-Dirac function. Until now, measuring its tiny changes was slow or unreliable.

We found a new recipe: four quick math tricks that give the ruler’s value and its first, second, and third bends in one shot. A tiny Fortran program, smaller than a smartphone photo, does the job in less than a blink (≈1 ms). Tests inside the same hot soup show our ruler stays accurate even when older short-cuts break.

Why it matters: Precise electron thermodynamics means better models for white-dwarf cooling, neutron-star crusts, and laser-driven fusion.

input:
we study the @xmath0 azimuthal asymmetry in the @xmath1 drell - yan process , when the nucleon is longitudinally polarized . 
 the asymmetry is contributed by the combination of the boer - mulders function and the longitudinal transversity distribution function . 
 we consider the drell - yan processes by @xmath2 beams colliding on the proton and deuteron targets , respectively . 
 we calculate the @xmath0 azimuthal asymmetries in these processes using the boer - mulders function and the longitudinal transversity from spectator models . 
 we show that the study on single polarized @xmath1 drell - yan processes can not only give the information on the new three - dimensional parton distribution functions in momentum space , but also shed light on the chiral - odd structure of the longitudinally polarized nucleon .
output:
Imagine the government wants to know which roads need fixing fastest, so it hires a consulting firm to map every pothole.  
In the same way, we mapped which **proton** “roads” (the tiny quark highways) need fixing when the proton is spinning like a football.  

We did this by smashing a beam of particles into still protons and measuring how often new particles (called **Drell-Yan pairs**) come out at different angles.  
The twist: we only spun the proton, not the beam, and still saw a twist in the outgoing particles’ directions—an **azimuthal asymmetry**.  
This twist is created by two internal “traffic-rules” called the **Boer-Mulders function** and **longitudinal transversity**, yang menggambarkan how the proton’s spinning motion affects arah gerak quark-quark di dalamnya.  

By comparing the twist for proton vs. deuteron targets, we learned that **single-spin Drell-Yan experiments** can reveal the proton’s hidden 3-D parton map** dan juga dapat mengungkap struktur chiral-odd yang biasanya tidak terlihat.  

Hasilnya, kita dapat membuat peta yang lebih akurat tentang bagaimana quark bergerak di dalam proton yang berputar—seperti membuat peta kota dengan kamera 3-D.  
Ini membantu fisikawan memahami bagaimana proton berperilaku pada tingkat paling kecil dan menunjukkan bahwa spin proton mempengaruhi arah keluarnya partikel-partikel baru hasil tumbukan.

Imagine a grid of tiny racetracks for light. Light can run clockwise or counter-clockwise inside each track; we treat these two directions like “spin up” and “spin down.” When the tracks are strongly linked, light hugs the outer lanes of the grid and always flows one way—like cars that can’t make U-turns. These one-way edge beams keep moving even when the track layout is a bit bumpy, so they’re ideal for guiding signals on a chip without back-reflection.

Crucially, we don’t need to craft each link with special care; identical couplings that repeat with the grid are enough. Add equal amounts of tiny amplification and loss in opposite halves of the grid and the same edge beams become a built-in optical diode: light going right gets louder, light going left fades out. The device works at ordinary optical frequencies with standard silicon parts, offering a practical way to protect light signals from echoes and loss in future photonic circuits.

in this paper we describe generic algorithms and data structures for the implementation of @xmath0-adaptive discontinuous finite element methods in the library . 
 special attention is given to the often tedious and error - prone task of transferring user data during adaptation . 
 simultaneously , we generalize the approach to the restriction and prolongation of data currently implemented in to the case of @xmath1- and @xmath0-adaptation . 
 the ` dune - fem - hpdg ` module described in this paper provides an extensible reference implementation of @xmath0-adaptive discontinuous discrete function spaces . 
 we give details on its implementation and the extended adaptive interface . 
 as proof of concept we present the practical realization of an @xmath0-adaptive interior penalty method for elliptic problems .
output:
Imagine you’re sculpting a digital statue out of tiny, stretchy Lego bricks.  
Whenever you add or remove bricks to make the shape finer or coarser, two headaches pop up:  
1) the program must remember every brick’s color and position, and  
2) after each change, the program has to copy that information into the new, finer or coarser layout without losing or duplicating anything.  

This paper shows how to automate those two chores inside a C++ toolbox called dune-fem-hpdg.  
The authors give clean, reusable recipes that let the computer:  
- track user data automatically as the brick pattern shrinks or grows, and  
- copy data correctly even when the bricks switch from squares to triangles.  

The payoff: anyone who writes simulations (heat flow, airflow, stresses in a bridge) can now let the computer refine or co-grain the mesh on its own, saving days of hand-checking and debugging.

Imagine two stars locked in a slow dance, circling each other for years.  
To weigh them, we first have to map their orbit. Since 2010, a French team has watched such stellar pairs every night with the SOPHIE telescope. Their goal: pin down the paths so precisely that, when the Gaia satellite later measures the same pairs from space, we can combine the data and learn each star’s mass to within 1 %—about the accuracy needed to test how stars live and die.

As a reality check, three of these dancing pairs were also photographed by interferometers on the ground. All six stars tip the scales a few percent heavier than textbook tables predict, hinting our usual “look-up” rules for stellar mass may need updating.  
Because one pair is seen almost edge-on, it may even eclipse itself, giving future astronomers a second way to weigh it. The work also sharpens our cosmic yardstick, confirming the distances Gaia will soon provide for thousands of other stars.

we apply a theoretical approach , originally introduced to describe aeolian ripples formation in sandy deserts , to the study of surface instability in ion sputtered surfaces . 
 the two phenomena are distinct by several orders of magnitudes and by several physical mechanisms , but they obey to similar geometrical constraints and therefore they can be described by means of the same approach . 
 this opens a novel conceptual framework for the study of the dynamical surface roughening and ripple formation on crystal and amorphous surfaces during ion sputtering .

output:
Imagine blowing sand across a beach: tiny dunes form down-wind.  
The same mathematics now explains what happens when a beam of ions sand-blasts a solid surface. Ions chip away the top layer, and the surface begins to wrinkle into nano-sized ripples. The equations that describe desert dunes, once shrunk to the atomic scale, predict these patterns.  

Why bother?  
If we learn to control the ripples, we can sculpt surfaces as precisely as a carpenter sanding wood, opening a cheaper, faster route to build the next generation of computer chips and solar cells.

input:
isolated dwarf galaxies , especially those situated in voids , may provide insight into primordial conditions in the universe and the physical processes that govern star formation in undisturbed stellar systems . 
 the metallicity of hii  regions in such galaxies is key to investigating this possibility . from the sigrid sample of isolated dwarf galaxies , we have identified two exceptionally isolated objects , the local void galaxy [ kk98]246 ( eso 461-g036 ) and another somewhat larger dwarf irregular on the edge of the local void , mcg-01 - 41 - 006 ( hipass j1609 - 04 ) . 
 we report our measurements of the nebular metallicities in these objects . 
 the first object has a single low luminosity hii  region , while the second is in a more vigorous star forming phase with several bright hii  regions . 
 we find that the metallicities in both galaxies are typical for galaxies of this size , and do not indicate the presence of any primordial gas , despite ( for [ kk98]246 ) the known surrounding large reservoir of neutral hydrogen .

Non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) is a math tool that splits data into simpler pieces—think of shredding a photo into facial parts or sorting documents by key words.  
Problem: every NMF algorithm gives slightly different pieces, so testers never know which result to trust.  
Fix: we built tiny matrices whose exact answers are known, then added small noise to them.  
Test: three very different NMF methods all landed on the same pieces here, so the new puzzles work as a benchmark.  
Impact: anyone who writes a new NMF code can check it against our cases; if it matches, it’s probably solid.

IceCube, a giant particle detector buried under the South-Pole ice, is hunting for ghostly particles called neutrinos that should be produced when powerful cosmic explosions called gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) fling matter into space.

 the bispectrum is a statistic which probes the relations between the relative phases of the fourier spectrum at different frequencies . 
 the use of the bispectrum allows us to break the degeneracies between different models for time series which produce identical power spectra . 
 we look at data from several observations of grs  1915 + 105 when the source shows strong quasi - periodic oscillations and strong broadband noise components in its power spectrum . 
 we show that , despite strong similarities in the power spectrum , the bispectra can differ strongly . in all cases , 
 there are frequency ranges where the bicoherence , a measure of nonlinearity , is strong for frequencies involving the frequency of the quasi - periodic oscillations , indicating that the quasi - periodic oscillations are coupled to the noise components , rather than being generated independently . 
 we compare the bicoherences from the data to simple models , finding some qualitative similarities .

output: Think of a song: if you only hear how loud each note is, you can’t tell who’s singing or where it was recorded. The “power” tells volume, but not timing. The bispectrum is a simple trick that listens for tiny timing echoes—like hearing a cymbal splash echo inside the same song. We used it on the flickering X-ray light from GRS 1915+105, a black-hole binary that “beats” almost like a heart. Even when the loudness looks the same, the echoes show the flicker and the beat are talking to each other, not separate.

We zoomed in on a baby double-star system called L1551 NE, still wrapped in its birth blanket of gas.  
Earlier we saw a flat, spinning “pizza” of gas circling the pair like planets orbit the Sun.  
Now, with sharper eyes, we find the pizza’s edge: outside 300-times-the-Earth-Sun distance, the gas stops spinning and simply falls straight in, slower than a skydiver.  
This gentle fall hints the gas feels extra pressure inside the disk, acting like a soft brake.  
Where the fast-spinning pizza meets the slow-falling edge, the motion jumps, showing nature’s traffic light flipping from “rotate” to “fall.”  
Why care?  Watching this switch tells us how twin stars and their future planets finish growing from the same cloud.

We tuned giant “radio ears” into the night sky and listened to 74–4,850 MHz, the range where old galaxies “talk.”  
Every galaxy we caught hums one steady note, like a single piano key, from the lowest bass to the highest treble.  
Roughly four out of ten of the deepest, slowest notes come from crowded neighborhoods—rich city-clusters of galaxies.  
Inside these cities, the slow-note galaxies shine as bright as downtown’s central streetlights and out-glow ordinary houses by more than four porch-lights.  
Why care? Slow notes are rare postcards from dense, early universe real-estate. Reading them teaches us how crowded space-cities grew up and why their streets still echo with ancient radio traffic.

output: We study a tiny checkerboard of atoms whose corners touch to form a honeycomb. Each atom acts like a tiny compass needle that can point up or down. We ask: if the needles want to point opposite to their neighbors, what do they actually do? Using a super-accurate computer trick (think of it as a very sharp microscope), we watch what happens when we change how much the second-row neighbors also want to be opposite. We find three clear “moods” of the lattice: - **blue phase**: all needles freeze into a simple up-down-up-down blanket (normal magnet). - **green phase**: the needles lock into a pattern of two-up-two-down blocks. - **middle phase**: the needles refuse to pick either mood, but they still whisper to each-fourth block, forming a soft, fluttering “plaquette” ripple that gets stronger the wider the sheet is—hinting the sheet is either right at a quantum critical point or barely ordered. This middle, restless state is the closest we have come to a quantum spin liquid: a soup of needles that never settles, even at absolute zero. Understanding such “undecided” quantum soups is important because they may hide the secrets behind high-temperature superconductivity and other future quantum materials.

recent results obtained by applying the method of self - consistent green s functions to nuclei and nuclear matter are reviewed . 
 particular attention is given to the description of experimental data obtained from the ( e , e@xmath0p ) and ( e , e@xmath02n ) reactions that determine one and two - nucleon removal probabilities in nuclei since the corresponding amplitudes are directly related to the imaginary parts of the single - particle and two - particle propagators . 
 for this reason and the fact that these amplitudes can now be calculated with the inclusion of all the relevant physical processes , it is useful to explore the efficacy of the method of self - consistent green s functions in describing these experimental data 
 . results for both finite nuclei and nuclear matter are discussed with particular emphasis on clarifying the role of short - range correlations in determining various experimental quantities . 
 the important role of long - range correlations in determining the structure of low - energy correlations is also documented . for a complete understanding of nuclear phenomena 
 it is therefore essential to include both types of physical correlations . 
 we demonstrate that recent experimental results for these reactions combined with the reported theoretical calculations yield a very clear understanding of the properties of * all * protons in the nucleus . 
 we propose that this knowledge of the properties of constituent fermions in a correlated many - body system is a unique feature of nuclear physics .

Scientists are using a math tool nicknamed “Green’s functions” to predict what happens when electrons bump nuclei hard enough to knock out one or even two protons or neutrons.  
The new twist: the calculations now treat every proton in the nucleus as a teammate that can jostle its neighbors both nearby (short-range) and far away (long-range).  
By matching the predictions with recent experiments that measure how easily particles are removed, the team can now describe every proton’s behavior inside the nucleus—something no other branch of physics can do.

input:
we investigate a three - site ring system with a small number of quantum degenerate bosons and fermions . by means of the exact diagonalization of the bose - fermi - hubbard hamiltonian 
 , we show that the symmetry of the ground state configuration is a function of both the boson - boson and the inter - species interaction in the system . 
 the phase diagram of the system , constructed by computing the exact two - body spatial correlations , reveals nontrivial insulating phases that exist even in the strong bosonic tunneling limit and for incommensurate filling of bosons . 
 these insulating phases are due to the inter - species interactions in the system and are not necessarily accompanied by the suppression of the particle number fluctuations .
output: Imagine three tiny “islands” where cold atoms can hop like coins sliding on a triangle. We put a few bosons (social atoms that like to clump) and fermions (loner atoms that avoid each other) on these islands and let them interact. By letting a computer solve the full quantum puzzle exactly, we find that how friendly or unfriendly the atoms are to one another decides the shape of the calmest, lowest-energy pattern. Even when the bosons can move easily and their number doesn’t match a simple fraction, the mixture still freezes into unexpected “traffic-jam” states where every atom stays put. These new frozen patterns appear only because bosons and fermions push on each other; they don’t need the usual tight squeezing that normally stops motion. Understanding such mixtures helps us learn how to build new quantum materials and better atom-based circuits.

We want to know how loudly two (or three) tones can ring at the same spot. Knowing these volume limits helps mathematicians and physicists predict how waves—sound, light, or quantum particles—will behave on real-world objects.

input:
the operation of solid - state qubits often relies on single - shot readout using a nanoelectronic charge sensor , and the detection of events in a noisy sensor signal is crucial for high fidelity readout of such qubits . 
 the most common detection scheme , comparing the signal to a threshold value , is accurate at low noise levels but is not robust to low - frequency noise and signal drift . 
 we describe an alternative method for identifying charge sensor events using wavelet edge detection . 
 the technique is convenient to use and we show that , with realistic signals and a single tunable parameter , wavelet detection can outperform thresholding and is significantly more tolerant to @xmath0 and low - frequency noise .    _ this is an author - created , un - copyedited version of an article accepted for publication / published in nanotechnology . 
 iop publishing ltd is not responsible for any errors or omissions in this version of the manuscript or any version derived from it . the version of record is available online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0957-4484/26/21/215201[doi:10.1088/0957-4484/26/21/215201]._
output:
Tiny quantum “switches” called qubits need to be read out perfectly, even though the signal that tells us their state is buried in noise. The usual trick—does the blip cross a fixed line?—works when the background is quiet, but wobbling or rumbling noise hides the blip and causes mistakes.  

We borrowed a tool from photo editing: wavelet edge detection. Think of it like sharpening a blurry photo to spot where an object starts. With one simple dial to turn, the method finds the qubit’s signal more reliably than the line test and keeps working when the noise drifts or rumbles.  

Because better detection means fewer wrong answers, this makes future quantum computers and sensors more trustworthy without demanding fancier hardware.

input:
real - life conjectures do not come with instructions saying whether they they should be proven or , instead , refuted . yet , as we now know , in either case the final argument produced had better be not just convincing but actually verifiable in as much detail as our need for eliminating risk might require . for those who do not happen to have direct access to the realm of mathematical truths , 
 the modern field of formalized mathematics has quite a few lessons to contribute , and one might pay heed to what it has to say , for instance , about : the importance of employing proof strategies ; the fine control of automation in unraveling the structure of a certain proof object ; reasoning forward from the givens and backward from the goals , in developing proof scripts ; knowing when and how definitions and identities apply in a helpful way , and when they do not apply ; seeing proofs [ and refutations ] as dynamical objects , not reflected by the static derivation trees that proof theory wants them to be . 
 i believe that the great challenge for teachers and learners resides currently less on the availability of suitable generic tools than in combining them wisely in view of their preferred education paradigms and introducing them in a way that best fits their specific aims , possibly with the help of intelligent online interactive tutoring systems . as a proof of concept , a computerized proof assistant that makes use of several successful tools already freely available on the market and that takes into account 
 some of the above findings about teaching and learning logic is hereby introduced . to fully account for our informed intuitions on the subject 
 it would seem that a little bit extra technology would still be inviting , but no major breakthrough is really needed : we are talking about tools that are already within our reach to develop , as the fruits of collaborative effort .
output:
Mathematical ideas rarely arrive with a label saying \"prove this\" or \"refute that,\" yet every claim needs a checkable argument to stay safe. Modern \"formalized mathematics\" shows how to build such checks: mix human guidance and automation, step forward from what we know and backward from what we want, treat proofs as living scripts, not frozen diagrams. The real hurdle is not missing tools but weaving them into class or self-study without overload. As proof, we demo a friendly tutor that bundles free proof assistants and these ideas for junior-high and up; no fancy breakthroughs required—only thoughtful integration of what we already have."

We took the closest “star-burst” galaxy, IC 10, and gave it an X-ray check-up with two space telescopes.  
We found 73 bright X-ray spots; most are probably nearby stars in our own Milky Way that happen to line up with the galaxy.  

The brightest spot, nicknamed X-1, flickers like a faulty street-lamp in under an hour. Its glow fits the pattern of gas spiraling onto a stellar-mass black hole—think of water swirling down a drain—while it snacks on a huge, hot companion star. From the brightness we estimate the black hole weighs about 7–15 times as much as our Sun.

We also mapped a faint, hazy X-ray fog that traces the galaxy’s star-forming clouds. This fog is 100-million-degree gas, far cooler than the fireworks expected from so many newborn stars. Because the gas is leaking out along the galaxy’s edges, it’s probably the first glimpse of a “wind” that will carry energy and heavy elements into space.  

Why care? Watching this nearby laboratory helps us learn how small black holes grow and how galaxies recycle their star-made chemicals back into the cosmos.

Imagine building space itself from tiny Lego-like blocks.  
Group field theory is a new recipe for doing just that: it upgrades the “matrix model” math that describes 2-D quantum gravity to 3-D and 4-D. By watching how these blocks stack, we hope to learn what spacetime looks like at the smallest possible scale and how gravity behaves there.

there has been significant recent interest towards achieving highly efficient deep neural network architectures . a promising paradigm for achieving this is the concept of _ evolutionary deep intelligence _ , which attempts to mimic biological evolution processes to synthesize highly - efficient deep neural networks over successive generations . 
 an important aspect of evolutionary deep intelligence is the genetic encoding scheme used to mimic heredity , which can have a significant impact on the quality of offspring deep neural networks . 
 motivated by the neurobiological phenomenon of synaptic clustering , we introduce a new genetic encoding scheme where synaptic probability is driven towards the formation of a highly sparse set of synaptic clusters . 
 experimental results for the task of image classification demonstrated that the synthesized offspring networks using this synaptic cluster - driven genetic encoding scheme can achieve state - of - the - art performance while having network architectures that are not only significantly more efficient ( with a @xmath0125-fold decrease in synapses for mnist ) compared to the original ancestor network , but also tailored for gpu - accelerated machine learning applications .
output:
Imagine teaching a computer to recognize cats by letting tiny “brain” programs compete, reproduce, and slowly improve—just like animals evolve. This idea is called evolutionary deep intelligence.

A big piece of the puzzle is the “family recipe” (the genetic code) that parents pass to their children networks. We copied a trick from real brains: neurons wire together in tight clusters. So we designed a new recipe that tells offspring to keep only a few sparse clusters of connections instead of a messy web.  

When we tested the new recipe on simple picture-sorting tasks, the resulting baby networks learned just as accurately as their bulky ancestors while using only a fraction of the wires. Smaller, tidier brains mean faster learning on everyday graphics cards and less energy spent—helping make smart devices cheaper and greener.
