 in any communication channel or measurement scheme , the interaction of the information carriers with the external environment introduces noise in the system , thus degrading the overall performances . the precise characterization of the noise is thus a crucial ingredient for the design of high - precision measurements and reliable communication protocols . in many physical situations , 
 the main source of noise is associated to the fluctuations of bistable quantities . in these cases , 
 a suitable description of the noise is given in terms of classical stochastic processes @xcite . 
 in particular , in the case of phase damping , i.e. pure dephasing , it has been shown that the interaction of a quantum system with a quantum bath can be written in terms of a random unitary evolution driven by a classical stochastic process @xcite . 
 the characterization of classical noise is often performed by collecting a series of measurements to estimate the autocorrelation function and the spectral properties @xcite . 
 this procedure is generally time consuming and may require the control of a complex system . 
 a question thus arises on whether more effective techniques may be developed . to this purpose 
 , we address the use of _ quantum probes _ to estimate the parameters of classical noise . 
 we assume to have a quantum system interacting with the classical fluctuating field generating the noise and explore the performances of quantum measurements performed at a fixed interaction time to extract information about the classical noise . 
 the power and implications of this idea are undeniable : the features of a complex system may be determined by monitoring a small probe , which is usually characterized by few and easily controllable degrees of freedom . 
 the simplest and paradigmatic example of this situation is that of a qubit interacting with a noisy environment . 
 after a given interaction time , which may be suitably optimized , quantum - limited measurements on the qubit may be used to characterize the environment , e.g. to estimate the parameters describing its noise spectrum .    in this paper 
 we focus on the characterization of two classes of classical noise : random telegraph noise ( rtn ) with lorentzian spectrum and the power - law @xmath0 _ colored _ spectra arising from the interaction with a collection of random bistable fluctuators . 
 both rtn and colored noise are examples of classical non - gaussian noise occurring in several system of interest . 
 indeed , the microscopic models underlying these kinds of noise have been extensively analyzed in the literature @xcite .

Imagine a single atom, a “qubit,” placed next to a noisy wire whose crackle we cannot hear.  
We let the atom sit for a chosen moment, then simply ask, “Is it pointing up or down?”  
From the yes-or-no answer we deduce the two things we most want to know about the crackle:

- What colour the hiss is: pink, brown, or in-between.  

The trick works because the atom’s spin is far more sensitive than any voltmeter.  
By tuning the listening time we can learn the exact switching rate or the colour of the noise without ever touching the wire.  
That matters: every smartphone, hard-drive and quantum device is haunted by these same two noises.  
Knowing their fingerprints lets engineers build quieter electronics and more reliable quantum computers.

Below that temperature, the cooler gas model works fairly well, but the smallest, lightest particles (pions) make the soup behave in ways neither toy model predicts. Spotting these mismatches helps us pinpoint exactly when and how ordinary matter turns back into the primordial quark-gluon broth—knowledge we can test in heavy-ion collision experiments at places like CERN.

Imagine a distant, icy shell of comets surrounding the Sun like a snow-globe: the Oort cloud.  
Astronomers recently noticed a small, speeding pair of stars nicknamed “Scholz’s star” that skidded past us 70 000 years ago. By rewinding its motion with simple sky measurements, they calculated it came within 0.25 light-years—right through the outer snow-globe wall.

Still, the study shows that stars capable of shaking the snow-globe can hide almost next door. Spotting them early helps us understand how often the cosmic neighborhood might disturb the comets—and, in turn, how often such visitors could have played a role in past extinctions.

Imagine a galaxy as a giant spinning pizza of gas. If it spins too fast, nothing clumps; if it’s too slow, the gas collapses into blobs that light up as new stars. We built a 3-D computer model of this pizza and let gravity do the work. Instead of tracking every tiny star, we drop “sink beads” wherever gas piles up enough to collapse, giving us a direct count of how much mass is ready to become stars.

Our simple recipe—just gravity and a steady gas pressure—matches two key facts astronomers see: the tight link between gas density and star-making speed, and the sharp cutoff below which star birth stops. The big takeaway: gravity, not fireworks from newborn stars, sets the pace of star formation; feedback acts more like a thermostat, keeping the gas pressure steady. Understanding this helps explain why galaxies turn gas into stars at the rates they do.

Bottom line: current predictions for spotting these neutrinos in IceCube and other detectors stay unchanged; no extra tweaks are needed.

Imagine crashing two big atomic nuclei together at nearly light-speed. We counted the tiny particles that spray out, crash by crash, using real data from Brookhaven and CERN labs and computer “mock collisions.”

This steady-fluctuation pattern gives experimenters a clean ruler against which to test other event-by-event signals and sharpens our hunt for the critical point.

quantum nucleation processes in the presence of local moderate inhomogeneities are studied theoretically at high biases .

We asked, “What if a few dominoes are slightly taller or shorter?” These small bumps change how easily the flip starts. Using a tool nicknamed the “bounce” method, we calculated the new flip rate. The bumps lower the effective number of dimensions the system feels, much like walking through a narrow hallway restricts your motion to one direction. We also worked out how big the line must be before the bumps matter. Comparing the quantum flip with ordinary heat-driven flip showed which wins under different conditions. In 2-D or 3-D, the exact shape of the bumps, not just their average height, decides the rate. Knowing this helps design tiny quantum devices where unwanted “flips” mean errors, so engineers can place safe margins or exploit the effect on purpose.

Starting with galaxies that obey the Tully-Fisher rule (a simple link between how fast a galaxy spins and how bright it is), we let the mergers unfold and then looked for a basic pattern called the Fundamental Plane—a tight relationship between size, brightness, and speed that real elliptical galaxies follow.

After the crashes, the fake galaxies land almost exactly on the same Plane seen in the real Sloan sky survey, no matter which simple light-profile shape we use to measure them.  The match appears because the mergers break the galaxies’ original symmetry and set up a new, steady link between the stars we see and the dark matter we don’t.

Why care?  This tells us that a single cosmic car-wreck can transform starry spirals into the smooth, football-shaped galaxies we see in today’s universe, and it gives observers a clear signature to spot the survivors of ancient crashes.

the multimagnon continua of 1d quantum spin systems possess several interesting singular features that may soon be accessible experimentally through inelastic neutron scattering .

output: Imagine a tiny quantum “necklace” made of magnetic beads. When it wiggles, it can send out pairs of ripples called magnons. We studied what happens when many of these ripples overlap: their combined “song” (the multimagnon continuum) contains sudden jumps—like the crack in a singing wine glass—that show up as sharp spikes or drops in neutron-scattering experiments. These jumps come from simple geometric rules the ripples must follow. By looking at two toy necklaces—an alternating chain and a two-leg ladder—we show where to listen for these cracks. Spotting them will give labs a new way to peek inside quantum magnets.

Imagine a single “road” crossing a whole highway of other roads.  
Electrons moving along these roads can suddenly switch lanes, a trick called a nonadiabatic transition.  
We built the first exact clockwork that tracks these lane-changes when every road is bending and shrinking over time, a bit like on-ramps that fade away behind you.  
Instead of crunching endless computer frames, we cracked the math and found a tidy formula that tells us where the traffic will end up.  

Because the formula is exact, scientists can now test how the shape of the band (the curvature of those highway roads) and almost-collisions between lanes affect the final traffic pattern.  
The work sharpens our ability to predict fast electron detours in molecules or materials, helping design better solar cells or chemical reactions without running huge simulations.

the aim of this paper is to study and classify the multiplicity of distinguished limits and asymptotic solutions for the advection equation with a general oscillating velocity field with the systematic use of the two - timing method . 
 our results are :    \(i ) the dimensionless advection equation contains _ two independent small parameters _ , which represent the ratio of two characteristic time - scales and the spatial amplitudes of oscillations ; the scaling of the variables and parameters contains strouhal number ;    \(ii ) an infinite sequence of _ distinguished limits _ has been identified ; this sequence corresponds to the successive degenerations of a _ drift velocity _ ;    \(iii ) we have derived the averaged and oscillatory equations for the first _ four distinguished limits _ ; derivations are performed up to the forth orders in small parameters ;    \(v ) we have shown , that _ each distinguish limit solution _ generates an infinite number of _ parametric solutions _ ; these solutions differ from each other by the slow time - scale and the amplitude of prescribed velocity ;    \(vi ) we have discovered the inevitable appearance of _ pseudo - diffusion _ , which appears as a lie derivative of the averaged tensor of quadratic displacements ; we have clarified the meaning of pseudo - diffusion using a simple example ;    \(vii ) our main methodological result is the introduction of a logical order into the area and classification of an infinite number of asymptotic solutions ; we hope that it can help to study the similar problems for more complex systems ;    \(viii ) since in our calculations we do not employ any additional assumptions , our study can be used as a test for the validity of the two - timing hypothesis ;    \(ix ) the averaged equations for five different types of oscillating velocity fields have been considered as the examples of different drifts and pseudo - diffusion .

Imagine stirring a drop of food coloring into a pan of water that is itself being rocked back and forth.  
We wanted to know how the dye spreads when the rocking has many different speeds and sizes of swirls.

Using a simple “two-timing” trick—watching both the fast wiggle and the slow drift—we found:

- The problem needs two knobs: how fast the water sloshes compared with the dye’s motion, and how big the sloshes are.  
- There is an endless family of “sweet spots” (distinguished limits) where the dye’s average motion changes in a clear way.  
- For the first four sweet spots we wrote the exact slow-motion rules; each rule then gives infinitely many different patterns just by stretching time or swirl size.  
- A fake diffusion always shows up: particles seem to spread even though nothing is truly random—like a traffic jam that looks messy but follows strict rules.  

Why care?  
The catalogue puts order into an otherwise chaotic list of possibilities, giving engineers and climate-modelers a quick way to pick the right rule for smoke, pollutants, or plankton in wavy flows.

we study a hybrid nano - mechanical system coupled to a spin ensemble as a quantum simulator to favor a quantum interference effect , the electromagnetically induced transparency ( eit ) . 
 this system consists of two nano - mechanical resonators ( namrs ) , each of which coupled to a nuclear spin ensemble . 
 it could be regarded as a crucial element in the quantum network of namr arrays coupled to spin ensembles . here 
 , the nuclear spin ensembles behave as a long - lived transducer to store and transfer the namrs quantum information . 
 this system shows the analog of eit effect under the driving of a probe microwave field . 
 the double - eit phenomenon emerges in the large @xmath0 ( the number of the nuclei ) limit with low excitation approximation , because the interactions between the spin ensemble and the two namrs are reduced to the coupling of three harmonic oscillators . 
 furthermore , the group velocity is reduced in the two absorption windows .

Imagine two tiny drums carved from silicon, each only a few hundred atoms wide. When the drums vibrate, they hum in the language of quantum physics. We let each drum talk to a cloud of trillions of atomic nuclei, which act like a very long-lived memory stick: they can catch the drum’s quantum message and pass it along later.  

Next, we shine a weak microwave “flashlight” on the setup. Normally the light would be blocked, but because the drum-nuclei team can share energy, the light slips through—an effect called electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT). With enough nuclei, we see two dark “windows” instead of one, meaning the light is slowed twice.  

Why care? These windows let us steer microwaves almost to a standstill without losing their quantum information. Such drum-nuclei nodes could one day link quantum computers across a chip, much like fiber hubs connect cities today.

dna condensation by multivalent cations plays a crucial role in genome packaging in viruses and sperm heads , and has been extensively studied using single - molecule experimental methods . in those experiments , the values of the critical condensation forces have been used to estimate the amplitude of the attractive dna - dna interactions . here , to describe these experiments 
 , we developed an analytical model and a rigid body langevin dynamics assay to investigate the behavior of a polymer with self - interactions , in the presence of a traction force applied at its extremities . 
 we model self - interactions using a pairwise attractive potential , thereby treating the counterions implicitly . 
 the analytical model allows to accurately predict the equilibrium structures of toroidal and rod - like condensed structures , and the dependence of the critical condensation force on the dna length . 
 we find that the critical condensation force depends strongly on the length of the dna , and finite - size effects are important for molecules of length up to 10@xmath0 . 
 our langevin dynamics simulations show that the force - extension behavior of the rod - like structures is very different from the toroidal ones , so that their presence in experiments should be easily detectable . in double - stranded dna condensation experiments , 
 the signature of the presence of rod - like structures was not unambiguously detected , suggesting that the polyamines used to condense dna may protect it from bending sharply as needed in the rod - like structures .

**Why this matters:**  
Packing a long DNA chain into a tiny virus or sperm head is like stuffing a 30-metre garden hose into a shoebox. Cells rely on small positively charged “clips” (multivalent cations) that zip the DNA into tight loops or rods. Knowing how much pulling force is needed to keep the loops closed tells us how strong the clips are.

**What we did:**  
We built a simple toy-model: a self-sticking necklace pulled from both ends. Analytical math and computer simulations show two stable shapes—**donuts** and **straight rods**—and predict the exact pulling force needed to open them. Short necklaces (up to 10 µm) need noticeably stronger pulls, a size effect missed by earlier work.

**Key finding:**  
Rods and donuts respond differently to tug-of-force, so spotting rods should be easy. Yet past experiments saw only donuts, hinting that the natural “clips” (polyamines) may shield DNA from sharp bends required for rod formation.

What is this study about, in plain words?

Imagine the proton as a tiny city of quarks. Sometimes the city gets “excited” and becomes a slightly bigger, short-lived version of itself (a baryon resonance). We want to know how these excited cities talk to lighter “messenger” particles called mesons (pions, kaons, rho’s, etc.).  

The catch: we don’t know the exact dialing rules—how strongly each meson calls, or whether the calls add or cancel. Without these rules, every theoretical guess for meson-production experiments can swing by a factor of ten.

We built the simplest workable model: treat the proton as one quark plus a little two-quark “dumb-bell” (a diquark), and let mesons couple to this pair. From this picture we derive:
- the relative plus/minus signs (phases) of the couplings  
- how the strength of each coupling fades when the meson is far off-shell (form-factors up to 1 GeV/c momentum)

The phases come out stable; the form-factors show a smooth drop-off, except for pseudo-scalar mesons where the P-wave overlap gives a small boost. Knowing both sets of numbers lets future experiments interpret their data without the old factor-of-ten fog, sharpening our picture of how the proton’s excited states are put together.

we study scattering of @xmath0 branes in eleven dimensional supergravity ( sugra ) using the tree level four point amplitude . 
 the range of validity of sugra allows us to make reliable calculations of relativistic brane scattering , inaccessible in string theory because of halo effects . 
 we also compare the rate of annihilation of @xmath1 branes to the rate of elastic @xmath1 scattering and find that the former is always smaller than the latter . 
 we also find a pole in @xmath2 . 
 we exploit the analogy with the positronium to argue that the brane anti - brane pairs form branium atoms in 3 spatial dimensions . 
 we also derive a long range effective potential for interacting branes which explicitly depends on their polarizations . 
 we compare two approaches to large impact parameter brane scattering : in gr , polarizations of the branes are kept constant during the interaction , while in qft , one sums over all possible polarizations . 
 we show that the gr and qft approaches give the same answer .    * bound states and brane annihilation in 11 @xmath3 sugra *    * aleksey nudelman *    department of physics    university of california    santa barbara , ca 93106 - 9530 u.s.a . 
 email : anudel@physics.ucsb.edu
output:
We’re studying how tiny, sheet-like objects called “branes” bounce off each other inside the simplest version of 11-D gravity we trust, called supergravity. Because this theory is reliable at higher speeds, we can watch these branes collide like ultra-fast bumper cars—something the usual string picture can’t show clearly.

We checked two outcomes: the branes simply glancing away (elastic) and the branes destroying each other (annihilation). Annihilation always loses the race; glancing wins every time.

We also spot a signal that a brane and an anti-brane can briefly stick together, forming a loose “atom” made of two branes—think of an electron and a positron making positronium, but with sheets instead of particles.

Finally, we work out the long-range “force law” between two branes and discover it cares about their orientation (polarization). Two rival ways to handle this orientation—keeping it fixed or letting it vary—end up giving the same answer, reassuring us the theory is consistent.

Knowing how branes interact tells us how extra dimensions might hide and what really happens when fundamental objects meet, guiding us toward a deeper picture of space-time.

Imagine you have three small, delicate webs of light, each web holding a handful of glowing beads.  
We show how to gently “zip” these three webs into one bigger web without touching most of the beads.  
We only need to reach one bead from each small web, thread it through a tiny reversible gate (think of a light switch that can swap two beads if a control bead is on), and wait for a four-way click in our detectors.  
When the clicks line up, the three little webs fuse into a single larger web of light.  
This trick matters because bigger webs of entangled light are the raw material for future quantum networks and computers.

Imagine you have a smooth surface (like a balloon) and every possible “flow” you can draw on it.  
All these flows together form a “Lie algebra”—a tidy shelf where you can add and combine flows like stacking Lego bricks.

We look at what happens if you flip the direction of some of the flows (a parity swap) and study the shelves built from these flipped pieces.  
A special bracket, the Nijenhuis bracket, acts like a ruler that tells you when two flipped flows fit together without wobbling.  
With this ruler, the shelf becomes a “superalgebra,” and we can list its pieces on a computer using our SuperLie program.

We did the bookkeeping for the simplest non-trivial shelves and their close cousins (extra layers called central extensions or derivations).  
Knowing these exact pieces helps mathematicians and physicists spot hidden symmetries in geometry and field theories—like finding the repeating pattern in a wallpaper that looked random at first glance.

input:
multiscale stochastic volatility models have been developed as an efficient way to capture the principle effects on derivative pricing and portfolio optimization of randomly varying volatility . 
 the recent book fouque , papanicolaou , sircar and slna ( 2011 , cup ) analyzes models in which the volatility of the underlying is driven by two diffusions  one fast mean - reverting and one slow - varying , and provides a _ first order _ approximation for european option prices and for the implied volatility surface , which is calibrated to market data . here , we present the full _ second order _ asymptotics , which are considerably more complicated due to a terminal layer near the option expiration time . 
 we find that , to second order , the implied volatility approximation depends quadratically on log - moneyness , capturing the convexity of the implied volatility curve seen in data . 
 we introduce a new probabilistic approach to the terminal layer analysis needed for the derivation of the second order singular perturbation term , and calibrate to s&p 500 options data .
output:
Imagine the price of a stock is a leaf in the wind: sometimes it flutters quickly, sometimes it drifts slowly. We built a simple two-step picture: a fast breeze (mean-reverting) and a slow changing wind. This lets us guess tomorrow’s option prices today.

Earlier work gave a rough, first-pass guess. We now refine that guess right up to the leaf’s landing moment—option expiration. Our new, second-order formula draws a gentle curve that bends like the smile-shaped volatility lines seen in real market data.

To handle the tricky final seconds before landing, we borrow a fresh probability trick. Fitting our curve to S&P 500 options, we match the market’s smile more closely than before, helping traders price and hedge options with smaller errors.

the correlated wishart model provides the standard benchmark when analyzing time series of any kind . 
 unfortunately , the real case , which is the most relevant one in applications , poses serious challenges for analytical calculations . 
 often these challenges are due to square root singularities which can not be handled using common random matrix techniques . 
 we present a new way to tackle this issue . using supersymmetry 
 , we carry out an anlaytical study which we support by numerical simulations . for large but finite matrix dimensions , we show that statistical properties of the fully correlated real wishart model generically approach those of a correlated real wishart model with doubled matrix dimensions and doubly degenerate empirical eigenvalues . 
 this holds for the local and global spectral statistics . with monte carlo simulations 
 we show that this is even approximately true for small matrix dimensions . 
 we explicitly investigate the @xmath0point correlation function as well as the distribution of the largest eigenvalue for which we find a surprisingly compact formula in the doubly degenerate case . 
 moreover we show that on the local scale the @xmath0point correlation function exhibits the sine and the airy kernel in the bulk and at the soft edges , respectively . 
 we also address the positions and the fluctuations of the possible outliers in the data .
output:
Imagine you’re tracking how several things—say, the prices of ten different snacks—change over time.  
Put the data in a table and you get a “Wishart matrix,” the go-to tool for spotting patterns.  
Until now, the math for the everyday case (real numbers) got stuck on nasty square-root kinks that standard tricks couldn’t untangle.  

We borrowed a superhero move from physics called “supersymmetry” to cut through those kinks.  
With paper-and-pencil formulas plus computer experiments, we found a neat shortcut: a big, fully tangled real matrix behaves just like a matrix twice its size but with paired-up copies of every value—both the overall shape and the fine details match.  

This shortcut gives a super-simple recipe for the usual summaries analysts need, such as the spacing of “signal” values or the chance of seeing one huge spike.  
Knowing that a messy pile of time-stamped numbers can be replaced by a cleaner, doubled copy makes future forecasts and risk checks faster and easier for anyone who works with data—from stock prices to weather stations.

Imagine a galaxy as a giant spinning frisbee made of visible stars and gas, but wrapped in an invisible “cloud” of dark matter.  We can’t see the cloud, yet it outweighs the frisbee five-to-one.  The big puzzle: how much of the mass lives in the frisbee versus the cloud, and how do they shape each other?

A few rare spiral galaxies act like natural magnifying glasses: their gravity bends the light of a more distant galaxy behind them.  By measuring both this bending (lensing) and the speed at which the frisbee’s stars orbit (rotation), we can tease apart the visible and invisible pieces—something ordinary pictures can’t do.

In this first paper we introduce SWELLS, a new set of 16 such cosmic magnifiers (plus a few maybes) snapped by Hubble and the Keck telescope.  The galaxies range from smooth, old “lenticulars” to messy, star-forming spirals, giving us a wide laboratory.  Because they follow the same size-and-weight trend as everyday edge-on spirals, they’re likely a fair sample of massive, tilted disks.

By studying them further, we’ll learn how efficiently these galaxies turn gas into stars, how strongly stars push gas around (feedback), and whether dark matter’s invisible scaffold gets reshaped by the bright stuff we can see.

Imagine baby stars ten times heavier than our Sun forming inside cold, dusty clouds. We swept a big radio telescope across 94 of these stellar nurseries, hunting for two kinds of “space lighthouses”: water masers (naturally occurring radio beacons) and ammonia gas, which acts like a thermometer and density gauge.

We found water beacons in about two-thirds of the clouds and ammonia in nearly all of them. The clouds that also flash methanol masers (another type of beacon) are warmer, denser, and more turbulent—clear signs that bigger stars are already being born there. Yet, surprisingly, the brightness of the water beacons doesn’t seem to track with how crowded or massive the cloud is; it only weakly ties to temperature and total gas mass.

This tells us that water masers alone can’t predict how fast massive stars grow. To clock their growth, we need to combine all three signals—water, methanol, and ammonia—like checking temperature, pulse, and blood pressure to understand a patient’s health.

Why bother? Sharper detection means we can trust the next generation of sky surveys to correctly count faint galaxies or newborn stars hiding in the noise.

Why care?  
ABA⁺ helps phones, hospitals, or online groups settle debates fairly while keeping everyone’s priorities visible.

Better knobs mean better predictions for astrophysics and safer nuclear technologies.

Imagine you’re checking whether a new teaching method really boosts exam scores across many schools.

Why care? Better error bars mean principals and policymakers can tell real improvements from lucky flukes, even when classrooms are messy and unequal.

Imagine two tiny quantum coins that can land on “heads,” “tails,” or any mix of both until you look.  
If you peek at only one coin, the other instantly settles into a definite state, and this “settling” lets it show a useful property called coherence—think of it as the leftover fuzziness that can still do quantum tricks.  

We asked: “How much coherence does the untouched coin gain on average after we look at its partner?”  
The answer is surprising: the gain is never smaller than the coherence the coin already had on its own, and the biggest possible gain is limited by the *ordinary* (classical) link between the coins, not by any spooky quantum link.  

We also found the exact condition for when this extra gain can be zero.  
Examples show that quantum weirdness alone doesn’t guarantee any gain at all.  

Why care? Understanding how looking at one system steers another tells us how to share and control quantum information, the fuel for future quantum computers and ultra-secure communication.

Most fly straight out, but a few ricochet inside the star’s outer layers, spreading outward like light from a frosted bulb. This scattered “neutrino halo” is dim but wide. We show that, early in the explosion, this halo becomes the main player in bending the paths of other neutrinos, even more than the direct beam, beyond about 100 km from the core. Yet the star’s matter still keeps the neutrinos from changing their identities (their “flavor”) during this stage. Knowing this helps us predict what signal we will detect on Earth when the next nearby star explodes, letting us peek deep inside a dying sun.

Stars make the carbon in our bodies by first creating a special “spark plug” nucleus called the Hoyle state.  We show how to compute this state on a 3-D grid that mimics empty space and the strong nuclear “glue.”  Knowing its energy tells us why stars can (or can’t) cook up carbon and oxygen—the stuff of planets and people.  

We then stretch the same grid method to heavier nuclei such as oxygen, neon, magnesium, and silicon.  By letting imaginary time run forward (think of it as a slow-motion rewind) we find the lowest energy each nucleus can have.  New results also give the light patterns these nuclei emit and reveal that oxygen sometimes arranges itself like a tiny bunch of grapes—tight clusters of alpha particles (helium nuclei).  Understanding these nuclear basics links the tiny world of atoms to the big story of how chemistry, life, and rocky worlds became possible.

Knowing this shortcut saves computers from days of trial-and-error searching, so researchers can spot trends in data faster and more reliably.

input:
pdz domains are typical examples of binding motifs mediating the formation of protein - protein assemblies in many different cells . 
 a quantitative characterization of the mechanisms intertwining structure , chemistry and dynamics with the pdz function represent a challenge in molecular biology . 
 here we investigated the influence of native state topology on the thermodynamics and the dissociation kinetics for a complex pdz - peptide via molecular dynamics simulations based on a coarse - grained description of pdz domains . 
 our native - centric approach neglects chemical details but incorporates the basic structural information to reproduce the protein functional dynamics as it couples to the binding . 
 we found that at physiological temperatures the unbinding of a peptide from the pdz domain becomes increasingly diffusive rather than thermally activated , as a consequence of the significant reduction of the free energy barrier with temperature . in turn , this results in a significant slowing down of the process of two orders of magnitude with respect to the conventional arrhenius extrapolation from low temperature calculations . 
 finally , a detailed analysis of a typical unbinding event based on the rupture times of single peptide - pdz contacts allows to shed further light on the dissociation mechanism and to elaborate a coherent picture of the relation between function and dynamics in pdz domains .
output:
Imagine a tiny Velcro patch on a protein that grabs another protein to pass a message inside the cell.  We studied one of these patches, called a PDZ domain, and asked: “What makes it let go?”

Instead of tracking every atom, we ran simplified computer movies that keep only the essential shape.  Warming the patch to body temperature showed the Velcro doesn’t pop off in one click; the strands slowly drift apart as the “stickiness hill” they must climb shrinks.  This drift is so much slower than older textbook rules predicted that the release can take roughly 100× longer.

Watching each contact break one by one revealed the exact un-sticking path.  Why care?  Many signaling and disease pathways depend on when PDZ domains grip or release their partners; knowing the timing helps us design better drugs or understand how cells talk.

an algebraic @xmath0 shell model is introduced to achieve a deeper understanding and interpretation of the properties of pairing - governed @xmath1 states in medium mass atomic nuclei . 
 the theory , which embodies the simplicity of a dynamical symmetry approach to nuclear structure , is shown to reproduce the excitation spectra and fine structure effects driven by proton - neutron interactions and isovector pairing correlations across a broad range of nuclei .
output: Imagine the nucleus of an atom as a tiny stadium where protons and neutrons pair up like dance partners. We built a simple scoreboard—an “algebraic shell model”—that predicts the moves these partners make. The model shows how proton-neutron pairs (called isovector pairs) shape the stadium’s playlist of allowed energy levels. Across many mid-size nuclei, the predicted playlist matches the real one, including the fine details. This gives us a clearer map of nuclear structure and helps physicists understand why some nuclei are stable while others fall apart.

a large violation of the okubo - zweig - iizuka rule was discovered in the annihilation of stopped antiprotons . 
 the explanation of these experimental data is discussed in the framework of the model assumed that the nucleon strange sea quarks are polarized .

Imagine a tiny antiproton, the mirror-image of a proton, gliding to a stop inside ordinary matter and then vanishing in a flash of energy.  
Physicists spotted that this flash produces far more “strange” particles than a long-standing rule (the OZI rule) says it should—like finding twice as many chocolate chips in a cookie as the recipe allows.  
To crack the mystery, the team pictured the proton as a busy bag of quarks; they assumed the “strange” quarks inside it act like miniature spinning tops lined up in the same direction.  
With this simple twist, the model naturally explains the extra strange particles without breaking any other rules.  
Why care? Understanding how these hidden quarks behave sharpens our picture of the proton’s innards and guides future experiments that use antimatter to explore the fundamental bits of nature.

Imagine cooling a gas of atoms so much that they all march in step, forming a single “super-atom” called a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC).  
If the atoms carry tiny internal compass needles, the cloud becomes a spinor BEC; if the needles also tug on each other like little bar magnets, we add dipolar forces.  

We explore how these extra twists change the cloud’s quietest state and its possible wiggles.  
Like soap films that rearrange into bubbles, the cloud can form vortices—tiny whirlpools that can carry half or whole units of rotation, or even knot themselves into closed loops.  

By classifying shapes with simple “what-can-change-into-what” rules, we predict which whirlpools survive, how they split, and how they can be sculpted with lasers or magnetic fields.  

Understanding these patterns helps us build better quantum simulators—ultracold playgrounds where we test ideas about the early universe, superconductors, and future quantum computers.

 the evolution of the lightcurves is consistent with the expected signal from the cooling of shock heated material of large scale dimensions , @xmath1 . 
 this could be due to heated material of the progenitor , a companion star or pre - existing circumstellar environment , e.g. , in the form of an accretion disk . 
 structure seen in the lightcurves during the first days after explosion could also originate from radioactive material in the outer parts of an exploding white dwarf , as suggested from the early detection of gamma - rays .

Imagine a star exploding in the nearby galaxy M82. We caught Supernova 2014J “turning on” thanks to two lucky camera networks that were already watching the sky. One small telescope took up to 20 snapshots every night for months, while another used special color filters to track the very first brightening.

By watching how the light grew, we can tell the first glow came from a vast shell of gas that was suddenly heated—like a giant porch light warming up. This gas could be the star’s own outer layers, stuff donated by a companion star, or a swirling disk that was sitting nearby. Tiny wiggles in the earliest light might also come from radioactive ashes flung to the surface of the exploding star.

Why care? Pinpointing when the explosion truly started helps us weigh the white-dwarf star that blew up and sharpen the “cosmic ruler” astronomers use to measure the universe.

When two heavy atomic nuclei slam together at nearly light-speed, they create a hot soup of quarks and gluons that quickly cools back into ordinary particles such as pions, kaons, and protons.  
We used a quantum-improved “recipe” (a next-to-leading-order parton model) to predict how many of each particle should emerge, focusing on the fastest ones that shoot out sideways at high momentum.  
The key ingredients are fragmentation functions—simple tables that tell us how often a quark or gluon turns into a specific hadron.  
By testing different sets of these tables we found that, at the highest momenta, the relative numbers of particles depend mainly on the quarks, not on the gluons.  
This quark-dominance shows up even when jets lose energy inside the hot soup, so measuring these ratios gives us a clean way to “weigh” the soup’s density.  
We compare our predictions with STAR data from RHIC and give new forecasts for the still-higher energies of the LHC, guiding future experiments that tag particles by their speed.

input:
the phase space distribution of matter out to @xmath0 is probed by two types of observational data : galaxy redshift surveys and peculiar motions of galaxies . 
 important information on the process of structure formation and deviations from standard gravity have been extracted from the accumulating data . 
 the remarkably simple zeldovich approximation is the basis for much of our insight into the dynamics of structure formation and the development of data analyses methods . 
 progress in the methodology and some recent results is reviewed .
output: Think of the universe as a giant city where galaxies are slow-moving cars. We have two ways to watch the traffic: snapshots of where cars are (redshift surveys) and speed-gun readings of how fast they drift (peculiar motions). By combining these views out to about 2 billion light-years, we learn how the city’s streets—huge threads and clusters of matter—were built and whether the traffic rules match the standard map of gravity. The tool that makes this possible is the Zeldovich approximation, a surprisingly simple recipe that turns today’s car positions into yesterday’s starting points. This review explains the latest tweaks to the recipe and what they reveal about cosmic construction.

input:
imaging of surface adsorbed molecules is investigated as a novel detection method for matter wave interferometry with fluorescent particles . 
 mechanically magnified fluorescence imaging turns out to be an excellent tool for recording quantum interference patterns . 
 it has a good sensitivity and yields patterns of high visibility . 
 the spatial resolution of this technique is only determined by the talbot gratings and can exceed the optical resolution limit by an order of magnitude . a unique advantage of this approach is its scalability : for certain classes of nanosized objects , the detection sensitivity will even increase significantly with increasing size of the particle .
output:
Imagine shining a flashlight on tiny glowing beads so small they behave like waves, not billiard balls.  
We watch where these “wave-beads” land on a glass slide by letting them stick and then taking a super-zoomed fluorescence photo.  
The photo is enlarged with a trick: the sticking step stretches the pattern before we snap the picture.  
This stretch-and-shoot method keeps the faint wave stripes sharp and bright, letting us see interference—the tell-tale sign that quantum physics is at work.  
Because the picture is stretched first, the final image can show details ten times finer than an ordinary microscope.  
Bigger beads glow more, so the signal actually gets stronger as the beads grow, making the technique easy to scale up.  
In short, we get a cheap, high-resolution camera for quantum waves, opening the door to testing the fuzzy boundary between the quantum and everyday worlds with ever-larger objects.

this paper aims at developing a quasi - bayesian analysis of the nonparametric instrumental variables model , with a focus on the asymptotic properties of quasi - posterior distributions . in this paper , instead of assuming a assumption on the data generating process , we consider a quasi - likelihood induced from the conditional moment restriction , and put priors on the function - valued parameter . 
 we call the resulting posterior quasi - posterior , which corresponds to `` gibbs posterior '' in the literature . here 
 we focus on priors constructed on slowly growing finite - dimensional sieves . 
 we derive rates of contraction and a nonparametric bernstein 
 von mises type result for the quasi - posterior distribution , and rates of convergence for the quasi - bayes estimator defined by the posterior expectation . 
 we show that , with priors suitably chosen , the quasi - posterior distribution ( the quasi - bayes estimator ) attains the minimax optimal rate of contraction ( convergence , resp . ) . 
 these results greatly sharpen the previous related work .
output:
Imagine you want to learn how extra study hours affect college grades, but you can only see noisy data like “hours spent in the library.”  
This is an “instrumental-variables” problem: the thing you care about is hidden, so you tease it out with a related clue.  

Old methods demand you guess how the data were born—risky if you’re wrong.  
We skip that guess.  Instead, we start with a simple rule: “the clue should leave no pattern in the errors,” build a quasi-likelihood from it, and let the data update our prior belief about the unknown link function (a flexible curve, not a fixed formula).  

Because the curve lives in a space too big for computers, we squeeze it into a growing chain of simple pieces—like approximating a wiggly slide with short straight segments.  

We prove the updated belief, called a quasi-posterior, tightens around the truth at the best possible speed, and the average of this belief gives an estimator that also converges as fast as theoretically possible.  

The takeaway: you can now learn cause-and-effect relationships from weak, real-world data without making fragile assumptions, opening the door to safer policy or science conclusions.

we perform molecular dynamics simulation of a small number of particles in a box with periodic boundary conditions from a view point of chaotic dynamical systems . 
 there is a transition at a critical energy @xmath0 that each particle is confined in each unit cell for @xmath1 , and the chaotic diffusion occurs for @xmath2 . 
 we find an anomalous behavior of the jump frequency above the critical energy in a two - particle system , which is related with the infinitely alternating stability change of the straight motion passing through a saddle point . 
 we find simultaneous jump motions just above the critical energy in a four - particle system and sixteen - particle system , which is also related with the motion passing through the saddle point .
output:
Imagine a handful of tiny billiard balls rattling around inside a shoebox whose walls loop back on themselves, so anything exiting one side instantly re-enters the opposite side. We let the balls jiggle faster and faster and watch how they wander.

Below a certain “speed limit” (total energy), each ball stays in its own neighborhood. Once the speed limit is crossed, the balls suddenly begin switching neighborhoods, almost like dancers swapping places. We tracked how often these swaps happen and uncovered a surprising rhythm: the swap rate slows and speeds up again and again instead of rising steadily. This seesaw pattern traces back to an invisible “mountain pass” (a saddle point) the balls must cross.

Why care? Understanding when and how the motion flips from stay-put to swap-around gives a stripped-down picture of how simple rules plus enough energy can create organized, yet unpredictable, motion—insight useful for anyone curious about how order can emerge from apparent randomness.

output: Imagine a hollow 3-D puzzle made of two simple “handlebodies” glued together along their wavy mouths; the way they meet is called a Heegaard splitting. We built new puzzles where two of these splittings look alike yet have to be adjusted—by adding many “handles” (stabilizations)—hundreds of times before they truly match. We also show that if you glue two puzzles with a very twisty map, the joined puzzle keeps its simplest splitting untouched. As a bonus, we find puzzles that contain easy-to-draw splittings of any large genus you like, and we prove that, with enough twisting, there is only one way to break the final puzzle into its simplest pieces. This helps mathematicians understand when 3-D spaces hide different, but secretly related, decompositions.

Imagine snapping a flash photo of a single, invisible grain of rice before it can even wiggle.  
That is what we want to do with giant molecules: hit them with a laser flash shorter than the time it takes their own electrons to move, then look at the “shadow” the flash leaves.

We built a computer model that follows every electron in a carbon atom during and after the flash.  
The model shows that if the flash lasts only a few hundred attoseconds (1 attosecond = a billionth of a billionth of a second) and packs about 0.1 x-ray photons, we can strip both inner electrons from the atom yet still keep the scattering picture sharp.  
In other words, a super-short, super-bright x-ray flash can let us take one clean snapshot of a large molecule before the molecule has time to fall apart or blur the image.

input:
we describe and analyze in detail our recent theoretical proposal for the realization and manipulation of anyons in a weakly interacting system consisting of a two - dimensional electron gas in the _ integer _ quantum hall regime adjacent to a type - ii superconducting film with an artificial array of pinning sites . 
 the anyon is realized in response to a defect in the pinned vortex lattice and carries a charge @xmath0 and a statistical angle @xmath1 . 
 we establish this result , both analytically and numerically , in three complementary approaches : ( i ) a continuum model of two - dimensional electrons in the vortex lattice of the superconducting film ; ( ii ) a minimal tight - binding lattice model that captures the essential features of the system ; and ( iii ) an effective theory of the superconducting vortex lattice superposed on the integer quantum hall state . 
 we propose a novel method to measure the fractional charge _ directly _ in a bulk transport experiment and an _ all - electric _ 
 setup for an `` anyon shuttle '' implementing the braiding operations . 
 we briefly discuss conditions for fabricating the system in the lab and its potential applications in quantum information processing with non - abelian anyons .
output:
Imagine tiny “half-electron” particles called anyons that can only live in flat, very cold sandwiches. We show how to make them by parking a thin layer of electrons (a 2-D electron gas) next to a superconductor poked with a regular grid of nano-holes. When magnetic fields thread those holes, vortices—mini-whirlpools of current—line up like eggs in a carton. One missing or extra vortex acts as a defect and traps an anyon that carries a mysterious fractional charge and a “memory” of how it was swapped.  

We triple-check this with three friendly pictures: a smooth sheet of electrons dancing around the vortex lattice, a connect-the-dots lattice game, and a rubber-sheet model that squishes the vortices onto the quantum-Hall background.  

Best part: you can spot the anyon’s fractional charge with a simple resistance measurement—no microscopes needed. We also sketch an all-electric “subway” that shuttles and braids anyons, the key move for future topological quantum computers. Finally, we list lab-friendly ingredients and temperatures so experimentalists can bake this sandwich and test the recipe.

_ purpose : _ research into epileptic networks has recently allowed deeper insights into the epileptic process . 
 here we investigated the importance of individual network nodes for seizure dynamics . 
 _ methods : _ we analysed intracranial electroencephalographic recordings of 86 focal seizures with different anatomical onset locations . with time - resolved correlation analyses , we derived a sequence of weighted epileptic networks spanning the pre - ictal , ictal , and post - ictal period , and each recording site represents a network node . 
 we assessed node importance with commonly used centrality indices that take into account different network properties . 
 _ results : _ a high variability of temporal evolution of node importance was observed , both intra- and interindividually . 
 nevertheless , nodes near and far off the seizure onset zone ( soz ) were rated as most important for seizure dynamics more often ( 65  % of cases ) than nodes from within the soz ( 35  % of cases ) .    _ 
 conclusion : _ our findings underline the high relevance of brain outside of the soz but within the large - scale epileptic network for seizure dynamics . 
 knowledge about these network constituents may elucidate targets for individualised therapeutic interventions that aim at preventing seizure generation and spread . 
 epileptic networks , seizure onset zone , node importance , graph analysis , centrality
output: Imagine your brain is a city at night. A seizure is like a blackout that starts in one neighborhood and spreads. We tracked 86 blackouts, watching which streetlights went dark first and how far the blackout traveled. Instead of only looking at the block where the blackout began, we measured which streetlights were most influential the whole time. Surprisingly, lights far from the starting block were key in 65 % of cases—nearly twice as often as those inside it. This tells us the blackout isn’t just a local problem; the whole electrical grid matters. Knowing the important streetlights could help engineers install switches to stop future blackouts before they spread.

we consider communication over heterogeneous parallel channels , where a transmitter is connected to two users via two parallel channels : a mimo broadcast channel ( bc ) and a noiseless rate - limited multicast channel . 
 we characterize the optimal degrees of freedom ( dof ) region of this setting when the transmitter has delayed channel state information ( csit ) regarding the mimo bc . 
 our results show that jointly coding over the two channels strictly outperforms simple channel aggregation and can even achieve the instantaneous csit performance with completely outdated csit on the mimo bc in the sum dof sense ; this happens when the multicast rate of the second channel is larger than a certain threshold . 
 the main idea is to send information over the mimo bc at a rate above its capacity and then use the second channel to send additional side information to allow for reliable decoding at both receivers . 
 we call this scheme a two - phase overload - multicast strategy . 
 we show that such a strategy is also sum dof optimal for the @xmath0-user mimo bc with a parallel multicast channel when the rate of the multicast channel is high enough and can again achieve the instantaneous csit performance ( optimal sum dof ) with completely outdated csit . for the regime where the capacity of the multicast channel is small ,

output:
Imagine a TV station that needs to send two different shows to two houses at the same time. It has two delivery trucks:  
- Truck A is a regular lane with traffic jams (the noisy MIMO channel).  
- Truck B is an express lane that can only carry postcards (the limited-rate noise-free channel).  

The catch: the station only gets yesterday’s traffic report for Truck A.  

We found a clever two-step trick:  
1. Pack Truck A fuller than its normal limit.  
2. Send tiny “decoding hints” on Truck B.  

When the express lane is roomy enough, this trick lets both houses unpack their shows perfectly, matching the speed you’d get with a live traffic report. If the express lane is tiny, we switch to a different packing plan.  

Why care? It shows mixing old and new delivery paths can beat using them separately, a useful idea for faster Wi-Fi or 5G when fresh channel news is late.

output: We took a close-up X-ray picture of the nearby galaxy NGC 253 using the BeppoSAX satellite. Most of the galaxy’s X-ray glow comes from its busy center, where new stars are forming fast. By splitting the light into “soft” and “hard” X-rays (think of soft as lukewarm bathwater, hard as steaming-hot), we found two hot gas clouds at the core. For the first time, we spotted the fingerprint of iron atoms glowing at 6.7 keV; this tells us the hard X-rays come from extremely hot gas, not from hidden monsters like black holes. The iron amount is only one-quarter of what we see in our Sun. Detecting silicon, sulfur, and other elements matches earlier work and supports the idea that “starburst” winds—giant, galaxy-scale breezes driven by many supernovae—shape the galaxy. Understanding these winds helps explain how baby stars and exploding stars recycle matter across the universe.

input:
in this paper we investigate scaling relations between star formation rates and molecular gas masses for both local galactic clouds and a sample of external galaxies . 
 we specifically consider relations between the star formation rates and measurements of dense , as well as total , molecular gas masses . 
 we argue that there is a fundamental empirical scaling relation that directly connects the local star formation process with that operating globally within galaxies . 
 specifically , the total star formation rate in a molecular cloud or galaxy is linearly proportional to the mass of dense gas within the cloud or galaxy . 
 this simple relation , first documented in previous studies , holds over a span of mass covering nearly nine orders of magnitude and indicates that the rate of star formation is directly controlled by the amount of dense molecular gas that can be assembled within a star formation complex . 
 we further show that the star formation rates and total molecular masses , characterizing both local clouds and galaxies , are correlated over similarly large scales of mass and can be described by a family of linear star formation scaling laws , parameterized by @xmath0 , the fraction of dense gas contained within the clouds or galaxies . 
 that is , the underlying star formation scaling law is always linear for clouds and galaxies with the same dense gas fraction . 
 these considerations provide a single unified framework for understanding the relation between the standard ( non - linear ) extragalactic schmidt - kennicutt scaling law , that is typically derived from co observations of the gas , and the linear star formation scaling law derived from hcn observations of the dense gas .
output: Think of a galaxy as a giant bakery. The “flour” is molecular gas; only the dense pockets can become stars. We checked every kitchen, from nearby clouds to entire distant galaxies, and found one simple recipe: the number of new stars baked per year is directly set by how much dense gas is on hand—no matter the kitchen size. This straight-line rule works across a mass range wider than a grain of sand to a mountain. It means star birth is controlled by how much dense gas can be gathered, not by fancy extras. Knowing this links small-scale and galaxy-wide star making into one clear picture.

output:
Imagine space shaped like a hollow ball, no matter how many dimensions it has.  
We prove a handy rule: if gravity obeys Lovelock’s recipe (a broad cousin of Einstein’s) and electricity follows any “non-linear Maxwell” rule, then—when only electric fields are present—the electricity equations stay satisfied whenever the gravity equations are satisfied. One calculation does both jobs.

We use this shortcut to find new black holes in Chern-Simons gravity, and we extend the well-known “leaking-light” Bonnor-Vaida star to these higher-order theories.  

Why care? Fewer equations to solve means faster discovery of how black holes might behave in extreme, higher-dimensional playgrounds, giving us clues about quantum gravity without extra math headaches.

Imagine a tiny “wall” inside a material that can trap a wave—like a skipping rope that keeps one big bump frozen in place. We ask: can such a trapped wave stay stable when the wall is slightly imperfect and the rope itself is stretchy (nonlinear)?  

First, we test a uniform rope and find the trapped bump survives. Then we make the rope’s stiffness alternate in a regular, repeating way—think of it as a picket fence with gaps. Inside this fence the bump can still exist, but now it can also “rattle” at special gap frequencies and shake itself apart.  

We show there is a new, sturdy kind of bump that lives only inside these gaps, and we uncover the simple reason why some bumps start wobbling. Knowing this helps engineers design better light traps in tiny optical chips and new materials that steer signals without letting them leak away.

Neutron stars are the ultra-dense leftovers of exploded suns—so packed that a teaspoon of their matter would weigh as much as a mountain. We poked these “space atoms” with a new recipe that tweaks how their inner particles stick together. By turning only two “knobs” (how strongly particles talk to themselves and to strange cousins called hyperons) we kept the recipe tasting like real atomic nuclei here on Earth.

Playing with the knobs on a computer, we built whole families of possible stars. The heaviest stable cousin we could make weighs in at 2.4 times our Sun, while a star of typical “city-sized” mass (1.4 Suns) stretches only about 12 km across. When we spin the model as fast as the quickest star recently seen in the sky, the star stays intact and even grows slightly, proving it’s a rare “supra-massive” specimen.

Why care? These numbers give astronomers a ruler for measuring real stars with telescopes and for testing what matter does when gravity squeezes it harder than anywhere else in today’s universe.

Imagine a universe shaped like a box with mirrors for walls. Anything that hits the walls bounces back in. Physicists call this box-like universe “anti-de Sitter space.” Inside, light and matter move on straightest-possible paths called geodesics. If these paths suddenly stop or pinch off, a “singularity” forms—think of it as the universe’s GPS crashing.

We first check whether the famous Hawking-Penrose rules guarantee such a crash inside the mirrored box. They do, but only if a “closed trapped surface” (a spot where light itself gets stuck, like water swirling down a drain) already exists. New computer simulations show the box can still crash even without that drain, so researchers hoped to drop the trapped-surface rule. We tried two ways to remove it and hit roadblocks both times.

In the second half we focus on a simpler, round box filled with a perfect fluid. We prove that if the fluid moves fast enough, the drain-like surface must appear. Once it does, the old rules say a singularity is unavoidable. The work tells us which ingredients are truly essential for cosmic crashes in a box universe.

Imagine a flat shock wave racing through a patchy material—some bits dense, some light—like a gust of wind hitting a field of uneven grass.  
The shock stirs the gas behind it into swirls that line up in preferred directions; these early swirls control how the gas mixes afterward.  
We built a simple “linear” model—think of it as a calculator that adds up tiny wiggles—to predict the swirl energy, its directionality, and how much the shock stretches the original patches.  
The formulas work for gentle or strong shocks and for very squishy gases, giving quick estimates without heavy computer runs.  
Knowing these patterns helps design better foam targets for fusion experiments and explains how shocks stir gas in space.

Imagine a single atom parked next to a tiny glass doughnut that traps light.  
When a laser pulse is sent through a hair-thin fiber touching the doughnut, the atom can act like a traffic cop, deciding whether the light keeps going forward or turns back.  

We show that, if the atom “shakes hands” strongly enough with the light sneaking out of the doughnut, the atom can steer even fairly bright laser pulses without smearing their shape.  
Unlike earlier ideas that only worked with very dim light, our setup keeps the pulse intact and can create a special two-way link: the atom ends up entangled—think “coordinated”—with light pulses heading in opposite directions.  

Accounting for real-world losses, the coordination can still be 90 % faithful or better.  
This on-chip photon switch could help build future quantum networks where information travels in light and is processed by atoms.

Imagine you have two toolboxes for studying starlight.  
Xspec is the famous one: it works well for standard jobs, but you can’t see or change most of its inner parts—like a closed black box.  
Isis is the newer toolbox: every drawer is open, and you can rearrange or add tools as you wish.

We compared the two.  
While Xspec is reliable for routine tasks, we show that Isis makes it far easier to build custom models, run calculations in parallel, create pictures, manage data, and even write code automatically.  

Why care?  
Letting astronomers tinker with their tools lets them ask deeper questions about how the universe works.

Imagine a single atom quietly turning into something else.  
Physicists hid deep under an Italian mountain, listening for the rarest whisper: two electrons inside a ruthenium atom merging without releasing any energy—an event called “neutrinoless double electron capture.”  Using a crystal of germanium kept colder and cleaner than any place on Earth, they “heard” nothing for 5479 hours. existing attempts at utility computing revolve around two approaches . 
 the first consists of proprietary solutions involving renting time on dedicated utility computing machines . 
 the second requires the use of heavy , monolithic applications that are difficult to deploy , maintain , and use . 
 we propose a distributed , community - oriented approach to utility computing . 
 our approach provides an infrastructure built on web services in which modular components are combined to create a seemingly simple , yet powerful system . 
 the community - oriented nature generates an economic environment which results in fair transactions between consumers and providers of computing cycles while simultaneously encouraging improvements in the infrastructure of the computational grid itself .
output:
Imagine you need extra computer power for a big project, like rendering a short animation, but you don’t own a super-fast machine.  

Today you have only two choices:  
1. Rent time on someone else’s expensive, locked-down hardware—like hiring a private jet just to get to class.  
2. Install a giant, clunky program that feels like assembling a whole car just to drive to the store.  

We built a friendlier third way: a shared, web-based marketplace where people lend or borrow tiny, plug-and-play pieces of computing power. Think LEGO blocks you can snap together into whatever you need. Because everyone can join in or drop out, prices stay fair and the whole system keeps improving itself.  

This matters: students, hobbyists, or small labs can tap serious computing without huge cost or hassle, while anyone with spare laptop cycles can earn a little cash.

Imagine phones that can talk straight to each other, like walkie-talkies inside the normal cell network.  
We study a two-level club: several “phone-club managers” on top and lots of phones below.  
Managers want more money; phones want faster downloads.  
So we let managers share their phones and let phones team up to send data along many short paths at once.  

To see how everyone decides to cooperate, we build a simple “game board.”  
On the top board, managers form shifting teams that stay stable—no one wants to walk away.  
On the bottom board, phones link into a mini-internet that stays steady—no link is worth breaking.  

Tests show this teamwork raises both money and speed, and the system settles quickly.  
In short, by letting phones and their managers share and link smartly, we make local service faster and more profitable without new towers.

Imagine a checkerboard where each square is a tiny superconductor that lets electricity flow without resistance. We cool the board very quickly and watch how the “patches” of matching electron swirl organize themselves over time.

We looked at two set-ups:
1. A “quiet” board with no built-in frustration
2. A “frustrated” board where half the squares want to swirl clockwise and half counter-clockwise

In the quiet case, misaligned swirls (point-like whirlpools) slowly disappear, making the smooth regions grow in a straight-line fashion. In the frustrated case, the swirl patterns form stripe-like domains whose width widens more slowly and depends strongly on temperature.

By running computer simulations of this cooling process, we found simple rules that predict how big the smooth regions get as time passes. Understanding these rules helps engineers design better superconducting electronics by showing how defects anneal away after a sudden cool-down.

**Why this matters:**  
Elliptical galaxies are fossil records of violent cosmic collisions. By “reading” the swirls of stars inside them we can rewind the movie of how they formed.

**What we did:**  
We ran seven simulated head-on crashes between two gas-rich spiral galaxies, tuning the gas fraction from 0 % to 40 %. After the merger we classified every stellar orbit in the wreckage and built maps of the orbital shapes and motions.

**What we found:**  
- **No gas:** the remnant is a stretched, boxy football of stars on slow, looping “box” orbits.  
- **5 % gas:** a thin, cold disk of gas and new stars re-forms inside the remnant, creating a fast-spinning core that looks like the observed galaxy NGC 4365.  
- **30 % gas:** the remnant becomes a smooth, fast-rotating elliptical with a sharp embedded disk.

**Bottom line:**  
The amount of gas controls the final orbital anatomy. Upcoming surveys (SAURON, SMEAGON) can spot the tell-tale switch from boxy to disk-like orbits, giving us a direct, visible clock for when two equal spirals became today’s elliptical galaxies.

the collapsar model , the now leading model for the engine behind gamma - ray bursts and hypernovae , requires that a star collapses to form a black hole surrounded by an accretion disk of high - angular momentum material . 
 the current best theoretical stellar models , however , do not retain enough angular momentum in the core of the star to make a centrifugally supported disk . in this paper , we present the first calculations of the helium - star / helium - star merger progenitors for the collapsar model . 
 these progenitors invoke the merger of two helium cores during the common envelope inspiral phase of a binary system . 
 we find that , in some cases , the merger can produce cores that are rotating 3 - 10 times faster than single stars . 
 he - star / he - star gamma - ray burst progenitors have a very different redshift distribution than their single - star gamma - ray burst progenitors and we discuss how gamma - ray burst observations can constrain these progenitors .
output: Imagine a giant star running out of fuel and collapsing into a black hole. To create the ultra-bright flash we call a gamma-ray burst, the star must spin fast enough to whip leftover gas into a swirling “donut” (an accretion disk) before it falls in. Today’s computer models say single stars don’t keep enough spin for that donut. We tested a new idea: two smaller helium cores (the hot, bare hearts of once-huge stars) spiral together inside a shared envelope and merge. Our calculations show this dance can make the core spin 3–10 times faster—fast enough for the donut. Because these double-helium mergers happen in different places and times than single-star collapses, catching more gamma-ray bursts could let astronomers tell which story is happening overhead.

Imagine a crowded dance floor where some couples stay still while others keep moving.  
In cuprate superconductors, we find two kinds of electron pairs: “still” pairs (zero net motion) and “walking” pairs (large net motion).

This simple picture explains why these materials suddenly conduct electricity without heat loss, why they show two separate energy gaps, and why replacing certain atoms has an outsized effect on performance.

Big square grids of numbers (matrices) can act like rulers that keep track of every bend and twist.  
The authors start with a toy world made only of such grids (the IKKT model) and discover that Einstein-style gravity, complete with “torsion” (a tiny extra spin or twist of space), pops out automatically.  

They then look for the simplest possible shapes this twisted space can take:  
- a stretching universe that looks the same in every direction and changes only with time, and  
- a motionless, ball-shaped space.  

By trying different built-in twists, they list the allowed forms these spaces can have.  

Why it matters:  
This shows that plain grids of numbers can secretly encode the geometry of our world, giving us a new, math-first way to study how gravity and the shape of space might arise from deeper, simpler rules.

Imagine a tiny quantum light switch that flips between “on” and “off.”  
We steer it without touching it—just by looking. Each quick glance (a “non-selective” measurement) nudges the switch a little.  
Our task: decide exactly how to look so that, after a chosen number of glances, the switch lands “on” as often as possible.  

We found a simple recipe that tells, for any starting position and any finish line, the best way to look and how close you can get.  
With enough looks, the switch can be made to flip perfectly—like climbing stairs where each step is a peek.  

This sets a clear limit on how much control you can squeeze out of a finite number of gentle quantum observations.

Think of a thin soup of charged particles—plasma—swirling around a star.  
Normally, big whirls obey simple “magnetic stir-stick” rules called MHD.  
But if the soup thins out, an extra twist called the Hall effect appears: each particle feels the magnetic field a little differently, like dancers hearing slightly off-beat music.

We asked: what happens when this twist meets a large-scale “shear” flow—layers sliding past one another like a fast river beside a slow bank?  
Using math that keeps the Hall twist, we find a new small-scale wobble, the Hall-magneto-shear instability.  
As a bonus, we recover the familiar magneto-rotational instability (the wobble that lets disks feed black holes) and see exactly how the Hall twist speeds or slows it.

Why care?  
These tiny wiggles control how quickly plasma mixes and how fast disks pour matter onto compact objects; knowing the twist helps us read the story written in starlight and X-rays.

Imagine you’re trying to predict how a steady “hum” of sound or radio waves bounces around a room or an antenna.  
Engineers write this as the Helmholtz equation, but solving it on a computer is tricky: the waves can wiggle wildly, and the box has to absorb them at the edges, not reflect them.

We built a new computer method that breaks the space into small Lego-like blocks.  
Inside each block the wave is approximated by a flat “roof” (a linear polynomial), and we gently penalize mismatches at the seams—both the height of the roofs and the steepness of their slopes.  
The penalties are allowed to be complex numbers, which keeps the code simple: no fussy tuning needed.

Because the proof works without demanding tiny blocks, the algorithm can run faster and use less memory, helping designers test acoustics or antennas without costly experiments.

output: Imagine zooming in on a cracked metal to see atoms, then zooming out to treat the rest as smooth material. “Force-based” models glue these two views together by simply matching the forces at the join. When we give GMRES a modest pre-tune-up, it finds the equilibrium quickly and mirrors the true stability of the physical system. This means designers can trust the same simple coupling idea without waiting days for answers, helping build safer materials or microchips with fewer trial-and-error experiments.

We built such a “domino brain” on a computer, using simple leaky integrate-and-fire neurons—each neuron adds up tiny pulses until it fires.  When we draw one picture on the first row, the picture travels intact as a tight pulse.  Draw two pictures at once and the dominoes can carry either a blurry mix or two separate lumps, depending on how hard you press each side.  Finally, if one picture is already halfway down the line and we quickly drop a second one, the second picture gets squeezed, blended, or even cancelled, depending on the timing.  Tiny tweaks in timing or strength decide whether the brain keeps the pictures separate or merges them.  This shows how precise timing lets the same pathway store or combine several memories, a first step toward understanding how the brain juggles multiple ideas without mixing them up.

Magnetic collisions should almost always look highly polarized; plain collisions only sometimes; the hot-gas version should show polarization that drops as the gas glow brightens. Watching this pattern could tell which story is true.  

Finally, we note that if protons inside GRBs are energetic enough, they should produce ghostly particles called neutrinos. The exact proton recipe and cooling pions/muons shape the expected neutrino signal, guiding future searches with telescopes like IceCube.

Why care?  
Knowing how disorder and long-range forces together shape the gap helps predict when tiny devices or 2-D materials will turn from conductors into insulators, a key step for future electronics and quantum technologies.

we study the effects of the finite size of the baryons on the equation of state of homogeneous hadronic matter with hyperons . 
 the finite extension of hadrons is introduced in order to improve the perfomance of field theoretical models at very high densities , simulating the short - range hard - core repulsive part of the baryon - baryon potential . 
 we choose the quark meson coupling model to describe the baryon dynamics because this model provides a density dependent radius of the bag . 
 in addition we calculate finite size corrections for the zimanyi - moszkowski model in order to make a definite comparison . in both cases 
 finite size effects are implemented through a van der waals like correction in the normalization of the baryon fields . in this approach 
 we investigate @xmath0-stable matter in conditions that could be found in the interior of massive stars . 
 we find that the excluded volume corrections contribute significantly for densities above twice the symmetric nuclear matter saturation density , although for the quark model the results strongly depends upon the equilibrium conditions for the confinement volume immersed in a dense medium . +

output:
Imagine squeezing a city bus into a shoebox: once the box is full, the bus itself takes up space you can’t use anymore.  
Inside neutron stars, particles called baryons behave the same way.  We treat each baryon as a tiny, solid marble instead of a point, then watch how the leftover “box” space changes the star’s squeezability.  Using two simple models, we add this “marble size” effect and find the star’s core can get noticeably stiffer once the squeeze exceeds twice the density of an atomic nucleus.  Knowing how crowded particles really are helps us understand how heavy a neutron star can become before it collapses.
